Note: Contracts subject to the Davis-Bacon Act are generally
required to pay at least the applicable minimum wage rate
required under Executive Order 14026 or Executive Order 13658.
Please note that these Executive Orders apply to covered
contracts entered into by the federal government that are
subject to the Davis-Bacon Act itself, but do not apply to
contracts subject only to the Davis-Bacon Related Acts,
including those set forth at 29 CFR 5.1(a)(1).

performance of work on the contract does not appear on this
wage determination, the contractor must still submit a
conformance request.
Additional information on contractor requirements and worker
protections under the Executive Orders is available at
http://www.dol.gov/whd/govcontracts.

operation to which welding is incidental.
================================================================
** Workers in this classification may be entitled to a higher
1/7/25, 11:01 AM SAM.gov
https://sam.gov/wage-determination/GA20250305/0 3/6

minimum wage under Executive Order 14026 ($17.75) or 13658
($13.30).  Please see the Note at the top of the wage
determination for more information. Please also note that the
minimum wage requirements of Executive Order 14026 are not
currently being enforced as to any contract or subcontract to
which the states of Texas, Louisiana, or Mississippi, including
their agencies, are a party.
Note: Executive Order (EO) 13706, Establishing Paid Sick Leave
for Federal Contractors applies to all contracts subject to the
Davis-Bacon Act for which the contract is awarded (and any
solicitation was issued) on or after January 1, 2017.  If this
contract is covered by the EO, the contractor must provide
employees with 1 hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours
they work, up to 56 hours of paid sick leave each year.
Employees must be permitted to use paid sick leave for their
own illness, injury or other health-related needs, including
preventive care; to assist a family member (or person who is
like family to the employee) who is ill, injured, or has other
health-related needs, including preventive care; or for reasons
resulting from, or to assist a family member (or person who is
like family to the employee) who is a victim of, domestic
violence, sexual assault, or stalking.  Additional information
on contractor requirements and worker protections under the EO
is available at
https://www.dol.gov/agencies/whd/government-contracts.
Unlisted classifications needed for work not included within
the scope of the classifications listed may be added after
award only as provided in the labor standards contract clauses
(29CFR 5.5 (a) (1) (iii)).
----------------------------------------------------------------
The body of each wage determination lists the classifications
and wage rates that have been found to be prevailing for the
type(s) of construction and geographic area covered by the wage
determination. The classifications are listed in alphabetical
order under rate identifiers indicating whether the particular
rate is a union rate (current union negotiated rate), a survey
rate, a weighted union average rate, a state adopted rate, or a
supplemental classification rate.
Union Rate Identifiers
A four-letter identifier beginning with characters other than
""SU"", ""UAVG"", ?SA?, or ?SC? denotes that a union rate was
prevailing for that classification in the survey. Example:
PLUM0198-005 07/01/2024. PLUM is an identifier of the union
whose collectively bargained rate prevailed in the survey for
this classification, which in this example would be Plumbers.
0198 indicates the local union number or district council
number where applicable, i.e., Plumbers Local 0198. The next
number, 005 in the example, is an internal number used in
processing the wage determination. The date, 07/01/2024 in the
example, is the effective date of the most current negotiated
rate.
Union prevailing wage rates are updated to reflect all changes
over time that are reported to WHD in the rates
in the collective bargaining agreement (CBA) governing the
classification.
Union Average Rate Identifiers
1/7/25, 11:01 AM SAM.gov
https://sam.gov/wage-determination/GA20250305/0 4/6

The UAVG identifier indicates that no single rate prevailed for
those classifications, but that 100% of the data reported for
the classifications reflected union rates. EXAMPLE:
UAVG-OH-0010 01/01/2024. UAVG indicates that the rate is a
weighted union average rate. OH indicates the State of Ohio.
The next number, 0010 in the example, is an internal number
used in producing the wage determination. The date, 01/01/2024
in the example, indicates the date the wage determination was
updated to reflect the most current union average rate.
A UAVG rate will be updated once a year, usually in January, to
reflect a weighted average of the current rates in the
collective bargaining agreements on which the rate is based.
Survey Rate Identifiers
The ""SU"" identifier indicates that either a single non-union
rate prevailed (as defined in 29 CFR 1.2) for this
classification in the survey or that the rate was derived by
computing a weighted average rate based on all the rates
reported in the survey for that classification. As a weighted
average rate includes all rates reported in the survey, it may
include both union and non-union rates. Example: SUFL2022-007
6/27/2024. SU indicates the rate is a single non-union
prevailing rate or a weighted average of survey data for that
classification. FL indicates the State of Florida. 2022 is the
year of the survey on which these classifications and rates are
based. The next number, 007 in the example, is an internal
number used in producing the wage determination. The date,
6/27/2024 in the example, indicates the survey completion date
for the classifications and rates under that identifier.
?SU? wage rates typically remain in effect until a new survey
is conducted. However, the Wage and Hour Division (WHD) has the
discretion to update such rates under 29 CFR 1.6(c)(1).
State Adopted Rate Identifiers
The ""SA"" identifier indicates that the classifications and
prevailing wage rates set by a state (or local) government were
adopted under 29 C.F.R 1.3(g)-(h).  Example: SAME2023-007
01/03/2024. SA reflects that the rates are state adopted. ME
refers to the State of Maine. 2023 is the year during which the
state completed the survey on which the listed classifications
and rates are based. The next number, 007 in the example, is an
internal number used in producing the wage determination.
The date, 01/03/2024 in the example, reflects the date on which
the classifications and rates under the ?SA? identifier took
effect under state law in the state from which the rates were
adopted.
-----------------------------------------------------------
WAGE DETERMINATION APPEALS PROCESS
1) Has there been an initial decision in the matter? This can
be:
           a) a survey underlying a wage determination
           b) an existing published wage determination
c) an initial WHD letter setting forth a position on
a wage determination matter
d) an initial conformance (additional classification
and rate) determination
1/7/25, 11:01 AM SAM.gov
https://sam.gov/wage-determination/GA20250305/0 5/6

On survey related matters, initial contact, including requests
for summaries of surveys, should be directed to the WHD Branch
of Wage Surveys. Requests can be submitted via email to
davisbaconinfo@dol.gov or by mail to:
            Branch of Wage Surveys
            Wage and Hour Division
            U.S. Department of Labor
            200 Constitution Avenue, N.W.
            Washington, DC 20210
Regarding any other wage determination matter such as
conformance decisions, requests for initial decisions should be
directed to the WHD Branch of Construction Wage Determinations.
Requests can be submitted via email to BCWD-Office@dol.gov or
by mail to:
            Branch of Construction Wage Determinations
            Wage and Hour Division
            U.S. Department of Labor
            200 Constitution Avenue, N.W.
            Washington, DC 20210
2) If an initial decision has been issued, then any interested
party (those affected by the action) that disagrees with the
decision can request review and reconsideration from the Wage
and Hour Administrator (See 29 CFR Part 1.8 and 29 CFR Part 7).
Requests for review and reconsideration can be submitted via
email to dba.reconsideration@dol.gov or by mail to:
            Wage and Hour Administrator
            U.S. Department of Labor
            200 Constitution Avenue, N.W.
            Washington, DC 20210
The request should be accompanied by a full statement of the
interested party's position and any information (wage payment
data, project description, area practice material, etc.) that
the requestor considers relevant to the issue.
3) If the decision of the Administrator is not favorable, an
interested party may appeal directly to the Administrative
Review Board (formerly the Wage Appeals Board).  Write to:
            Administrative Review Board
            U.S. Department of Labor
            200 Constitution Avenue, N.W.
            Washington, DC 20210.
================================================================
          END OF GENERAL DECISION"

THE FOLLOWING PUBLICATIONS AND AUTHORITIES HAVING JURISDICTION SHALL 
BE REFERENCED FOR  THE DESIGN OF THE FIRE ALARM DETECTION SYSTEM ON 
THIS PROJECT: 
1. NFPA 1 - FIRE CODE, 2021 EDITION 
2. NFPA 10 - STANDARD FOR PORTABLE FIRE EXTINGUISHERS, 2022 EDITION 
3. NFPA 70 - NATIONAL ELECTRIC CODE, 2023 EDITION 
4. NFPA 72 - NATIONAL FIRE ALARM AND SIGNALING CODE, 2022 EDITION 
5. NFPA 101 - LIFE SAFETY CODE. 2021 EDITION 
6. NFPA 241 - STANDARD FOR SAFEGUARDING CONSTRUCTION, ALTERNATION AND 
DEMOLITION OPERATIONS, 2019 EDITION 
7. VA FIRE PROTECTION DESIGN MANUAL,EIGHTH EDITION 
8. VA SEISMIC DESIGN REQUIREMENTS, REVISED MAY 1, 2020 EDITION 
9. ANSI, A117.1 STANDARD, ACCESSIBLE AND USABLE BUILDINGS AND FACILITIES. 2017 
EDITION 
10. VA FIRE SAFETY 
1. THE CONTRACTOR WILL BE HELD RESPONSIBLE TO HAVE EXAMINED THE EXISTING SITE CONDITIONS FOR 
THE WORK INCLUDED UNDER THIS CONTRACT. NO ALLOWANCE WILL BE MADE SUBSEQUENTLY IN THIS 
CONNECTION ON BEHALF OF THE CONTRACTOR FOR ANY ERROR OR NEGLIGENCE ON THEIR PART. 
2. NO FIRE ALARM DOCUMENTS/PLANS SHALL BE USED FOR DEMOLITION AND INSTALLATION OF THIS 
SYSTEM UNLESS THEY CONTAIN A REVIEW AND APPROVAL STAMP FROM THE VA FIRE SAFETY AND A 
COMPLETED REVIEW BY THE ARCHITECT/ENGINEER. THE VA FIRE SAFETY OR ARCHITECT/ENGINEER HAS 
THE AUTHORITY TO STOP ANY WORK UNTIL SUCH PLANS ARE ON SITE AND IN USE. 
3. ALL FIRE ALARM DEVICE LOCATIONS SHALL BE COORDINATED WITH LIGHT FIXTURES, HVAC DIFFUSERS, 
SPRINKLERS, SIGNS, AND OTHER MEP TRADES PRIOR TO CONSTRUCTION. 
4. SMOKE DETECTORS SHALL NOT BE INSTALLED WITHIN THREE FEET OF DIRECT AIRFLOW OR AN AIR 
SUPPLY DIFFUSER OR RETURN AIR OPENING. 
5. FIRE ALARM CONTRACTOR SHALL SEAL ALL FIRE RATED WALL PARTITIONS WITH UL LISTED MATERIAL 
AND METHODS. 
6. THE FIRE ALARM CONTRACTOR SHALL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR THE COMPLETE DESIGN OF THE LAYOUTS, 
DEVICES COUNTS, CONDUCTOR TYPES, WIRING DIAGRAMS, I/O MATRIX, RISER DIAGRAMS, AND BATTERY 
CALCULATIONS SHALL BE SEALED BY AN PROFESSIONAL ENGINEER REGISTERED IN THE STATE OF 
GEORGIA OR A NICET LEVEL III OR LEVEL IV FIRE ALARM DESIGNER. 
7. FLOOR/WALL PENETRATIONS THROUGH RATED SEPARATIONS SHALL BE SEALED WITH AN APPROVED 
FIRE RATED MATERIAL. 
8. WALL PENETRATIONS THROUGH NON -RATED PARTITIONS SHALL BE PROVIDED WITH A NON -SHRINKING 
GROUT OR CAULKING MATERIAL AND APPROVED ASSEMBLY.

A. THE FIRE ALARM CONTRACTOR SHALL BE REQUIRED TO HAVE AN OVERALL FIRE SAFETY PROGRAM 
THAT SHALL INCLUDE: 
B. FIRE PROTECTION SERVICES AS FOLLOWS: 
1. DURING DEMOLITION OF THE EXISTING SCOPE OF WORK AREA PRESERVATION OF EXISTING 
SYSTEMS DURING DEMOLITION SHALL BE KEPT FULLY OPERATIONAL AS LONG AS FEASIBLY 
POSSIBLE AND KEEP DISRUPTIONS TO FIRE ALARM AND FIRE SPRINKLER SYSTEM SHALL BE 
KEPT TO A MINIMUM. 
2. COORDINATE REQUIREMENTS AND RESPONSIBILITIES WITH VA FIRE SAFETY REPRESENTATIVE 
ON RESPONSIBILITIES OF FIRE FIGHTING OR CONTACTING OF LOCAL FIRE DEPARTMENT. 
CLEARLY DELINEATE THE DIVISION OF RESPONSIBILITIES BETWEEN THE VA AND CONTRACTOR 
DURING A FIRE INCIDENT. 
3. DEVELOPMENT AND DOCUMENTATION OF A PRE -FIRE PLAN WITH THE VA FIRE SAFETY OFFICIAL 
AND THE LOCAL FIRE DEPARTMENT THAT WOULD PROVIDE FIRE FIGHTING SERVICES DURING A 
FIRE OCCURRENCE. 
4. RAPID COMMUNICATION WITH THE VA FIRE SAFETY OFFICIAL. 
5. CONSIDERATION OF SPECIAL HAZARDS RESULTING FROM PREVIOUS SPACE USE. 
C. PROTECTION OF EXISTING STRUCTURES AND EQUIPMENT FROM EXPOSURE FIRES RESULTING 
FROM CONSTRUCTION, ALTERATION AND DEMOLITION OPERATIONS. 
1. VA RESPONSIBILITIES FOR FIRE PROTECTION: 
a. THE VA SHALL DESIGNATE A PERSON WHO SHALL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR THE FIRE 
PREVENTION PROGRAM AND WHO SHALL ENSURE THAT IT IS CARRIED OUT TO 
COMPLETION. 
b. THE VA FIRE PREVENTION MANAGER SHALL HAVE THE AUTHORITY TO ENFORCE THE 
PROVISION OS THIS AND OTHER APPLICABLE FIRE PROTECTION STANDARDS. 
c. THE VA FIRE PREVENTION PROGRAM MANAGER SHALL HAVE THE KNOWLEDGE OF THE 
APPLICABLE FIRE PROTECTION STANDARDS, AVAILABLE FIRE PROTECTION SYSTEMS AND 
FIRE INSPECTION PROCEDURES. 
d. THE VA FIRE PROTECTION INSPECTION RECORDS SHALL BE AVAILABLE FOR REVIEW BY ANY 
AUTHORITY HAVING JURISDICTION. 
D. FIRE ALARM REQUIREMENTS: 
1. THE FIRE ALARM CONTRACTOR SHALL COORDINATE WITH THE VA FIRE OFFICIAL AS TO THE 
CLOSEST READILY ACCESSIBLE PUBLIC FIRE ALARM BOX NEAR THE CONSTRUCTION PREMISE 
TO REPORT A FIRE INCIDENT OR OCCURRENCE. 
a. INSTRUCTIONS SHALL BE CREATED AND ISSUED FOR ALL CONTRACTOR AND SUB -TIER 
CONTRACTORS FOR PROCEDURES FOR IMMEDIATE NOTIFICATION TO THE VA FIRE SAFETY 
REPRESENTATIVE AND/OR LOCAL FIRE DEPARTMENT IN THE CASE OF A FIRE. WHERE 
TELEPHONE SERVICE IS EMPLOYED, E.G., CELLULAR OF LAND LINE SERVICE TO THE 
RESPONDING FIRE DEPARTMENT OR EQUIVALENT FACILITIES. 
2. THE FIRE ALARM CONTRACTOR SHALL PROVIDE, FURNISH AND INSTALL, NEW FIXED 
TEMPERATURE HEAT DETECTORS IN THE WORK AREA DURING CONSTRUCTION AND THE HEAT 
DETECTORS ARE PROVIDED AS AN INTERIM EQUIVALENT SAFETY MEASURE TO BE PROVIDED 
DURING A FIRE ALARM OR FIRE SUPPRESSION SYSTEM IMPAIRMENT, RENOVATION TO EXISTING 
SCOPE OF WORK AREA.  COORDINATE WITH VA CONTRACTING OFFICER REPRESENTATIVE AND 
DESIGNATED FIRE SAFETY OFFICIAL. 
3. THE HEAT DETECTORS SPACING WITHIN THE CONSTRUCTION AREAS SHALL FOLLOW NFPA 72 
AND NFPA 241 REQUIREMENTS. THE HEAT DETECTORS SHALL BE CONFIGURED/INTERFACED 
WITH THE NEW LOCAL FIRE ALARM PANEL AND THE SITE'S EXISTING MAIN FIRE ALARM AND 
DETECTION SYSTEM FOR MONITORING DURING A SYSTEM IMPAIRMENT AND DURING THE 
RENOVATION OF EXISTING CONDITIONS FOR THE SCOPE OF WORK AREA. 
4. THE TEMPORARY FIRE DETECTION SYSTEM FOR THE EXISTING SCOPE OF WORK AREA SHALL 
BE FULLY OPERATIONAL PRIOR TO ANY SIGNIFICANT COMBUSTIBLE MATERIALS ARE PRESENT 
WITHIN THE PERIMETER OF THE BUILDING. 
5. THE TEMPORARY FIRE DETECTION SYSTEM FOR RENOVATED AREAS AND NEW CONSTRUCTION 
BUILDING SHALL INCLUDE THE HEAT DETECTORS INCLUDING ALL WIRING, PROGRAMMING, ETC., 
TO/FROM THE INDIVIDUAL DEVICES TO THE LOCAL FIRE ALARM PANEL AND INTERFACE WITH 
THE MAIN FIRE ALARM CONTROL PANEL FOR 24/7 MONITORING IS A PROJECT REQUIREMENT. 
THE TEMPORARY FIRE ALARM DEVICES SHALL BE REMOVED OR LEFT IN PLACE DEPENDENT ON 
THE COR'S REQUIREMENT. 
6. ALL SHUTDOWNS SHALL BE COORDINATED AND APPROVED THROUGH THE COR'S 
REPRESENTATIVE AND SHALL REQUIRE A MINIMUM OF 15 DAYS ADVANCED NOTICE, THIS TIME 
LENGTH MAY BE LONGER OF SHORTER FOR SOME SHUTDOWNS AND SHALL BE AT THE COR'S 
DISCRETION. DRAINING AND REFILLING OF THE EXISTING SYSTEM IS A RESPONSIBILITY OF THE 
COR'S REPRESENTATIVE. 
7. ALL DISRUPTIONS IN THE FIRE SUPPRESSION SYSTEM SHALL BE COMPENSATED WITH AN 
APPROVED FIRE WATCH AND STANDBY PERSONAL. 
TEMPORARY FIRE ALARM, FIRE EXTINGUISHERS AND FIRE SUPPRESSION REQUIREMENTS 
E. FIRE EXTINGUISHERS REQUIREMENTS: 
A. THE FIRE ALARM CONTRACTOR'S CONSTRUCTION OF THE SCOPE OF WORK AREA SHALL 
REQUIRE THE PLACEMENT OF FIRE EXTINGUISHERS AS FOLLOWS: 
• THE FIRE ALARM CONTRACTOR PROVIDE AT EACH LOCATION A PORTABLE FIRE 
EXTINGUISHER SHALL BE PROVIDED WHERE HAZARDS EXIST, SUCH AS THE STORAGE AND 
USED OF FLAMMABLE AND COMBUSTIBLE LIQUIDS OR COMBUSTIBLE MATERIAL ARE 
PRESENT WITHIN THE PERIMETER OF THE BUILDING CONSTRUCTION. 
• FIRE EXTINGUISHERS SHALL BE LOCATED SO THAT THE TRAVEL DISTANCE TO A FIRE 
EXTINGUISHER DOES NOT EXCEED FIFTY FEET. 
• FIRE EXTINGUISHERS TO BE PROVIDED DURING CONSTRUCTION SHALL BE EQUAL TO A 10 
LB., FIRE EXTINGUISHER DRY CHEMICAL (4A:80B:C) FOR HEALTH CARE OCCUPANCIES TO 
INCLUDE THE ENTIRE BUILDING FLOOR AREA. 
F. FLAMMABLE AND COMBUSTIBLE LIQUIDS: 
a. STORAGE OF FLAMMABLE AND COMBUSTIBLE LIQUIDS SHALL BE IN ACCORDANCE WITH NFPA 30 
AND NFPA 241, SECTION 5.5 
G. OPERATION OF VALVES: OPERATION OF SPRINKLER CONTROL VALVES SHALL BE PERMITTED ONLY 
BY AUTHORIZED PERSONNEL AND SHALL BE ACCOMPANIED BY NOTIFICATION OF DULY 
DESIGNATED PARTIES. WHEN THE SPRINKLER SYSTEM IS BEING REGULARLY TURNED OFF TO 
FACILITATE CONNECTION OF NEWLY COMPLETED SEGMENTS, THE SPRINKLER CONTROL VALVE 
SHALL BE CHECKED AT THE END OF EACH WORK DAY BY THE FIRE SUPPRESSION CONTRACTOR 
AND THE VA FIRE SAFETY OFFICIAL TO ASCERTAIN THAT THE PROTECTION IS IN SERVICE.

THE FIRE ALARM NOTIFICATION SYSTEM SHALL GO INTO ALARM UPON ACTIVATION OF A MANUAL PULL, AREA SMOKE DETECTOR, DUCT SMOKE 
DETECTOR, OR FLOW SWITCH. THE ALARM SHALL BE DISPLAYED BY AUDIBLE AND VISUAL NOTIFICATION APPLIANCES. THE AIR HANDLING 
UNITS WILL SHUTDOWN THROUGH INTERFACE BETWEEN THE FIRE ALARM SYSTEM AND THE AIR HANDLER CONTROL PANEL. THE FIRE ALARM 
SYSTEM SHALL DISPLAY A TROUBLE CONDITION UNDER LOSS OF POWER, OR IF A SMOKE DETECTOR IS REMOVED FROM THE BASE. THE FIRE 
ALARM SYSTEM SHALL DISPLAY A SUPERVISORY CONDITION UPON ACTIVATION OF A TAMPER SWITCH OR DUCT SMOKE DETECTOR.

PROCEDURES FOR DRAINING WET PIPE SYSTEM 
1. TO DRAIN A WET PIPE SYSTEM THE PROCEDURE TO BE PERFORMED AND SUBMITTED TO THE ARCHITECT, 
ENGINEER, VA COR, AND VA FIRE SAFETY OFFICIAL SHOULD INCLUDE BUT NOT LIMITED TO THE 
FOLLOWING. 
1.1. CLOSE ALL SPRINKLER CONTROL VALVES. 
1.2. TAG ALL CLOSED VALVES. 
1.3. OPEN MAIN DRAIN VALVES AND AUXILIARY DRAINS ALLOWING THE SYSTEM FOR 100% COMPLETE 
DRAINAGE. 
1.4. WHEN THE WATER HAS BEEN COMPLETELY DRAINED, CLOSE THE MAIN DRAIN AND AUXILIARY 
DRAIN VALVES. WHEN THE WATER HAS STOPPED FLOWING, CHECK ALL CONTROL VALVES TO BE 
SURE THEY ARE TIGHTLY SHUT; ANY MALFUNCTION CONTROL VALVES SHOULD BE REPAIRED 
AND/OR REPLACED IMMEDIATELY AS DEEMED APPLICABLE. 
1.5. CHECK FOR WATER TRAPPED AT ALL LOW POINTS IN PIPING THAT LACK AUXILIARY DRAINS; 
REMOVE DRAIN AND REPLACE SUCH PIPING. 
1.6. ONCE ABOVE ITEM ARE CONFIRMED WITH 100% CERTAINTY THE CONTRACTOR SHALL PERFORM 
ALL NEW INSTALLATIONS. 
1. MINIMUM REQUIREMENTS 
A. THE FIRE ALARM/FIRE SUPPRESSION CONTRACTOR SHALL ENACT MEASURES THAT SHALL BE 
TAKEN DURING THE IMPAIRMENT TO ENSURE THAT INCREASED RISKS ARE MINIMIZED AND THE 
DURATION OF THE IMPAIRMENT IS LIMITED. 
B. THE FIRE ALARM CONTRACTOR SHALL NOTIFY IN WRITING TO THE ARCHITECT, ENGINEER, VA 
COR, AND VA FIRE SAFETY OFFICIALOF THE PLANNED IMPAIRMENT, PROCEDURES DURING THE 
IMPAIRMENT, TESTING RE -COMMISSIONING OF THE WET -PIPE FIRE PROTECTION/FIRE ALARM 
SYSTEMS FOR PROTECTION OF THE AFFECTED LOCATIONS WITHIN THE SCOPE OF WORK 
SUITE. 
C. THE FIRE SUPPRESSION CONTRACTOR THROUGH THE VA COR SHALL PREPARE AND SUBMIT TO 
THE VA COR FOR THE VA COR'S DISTRIBUTION TO THE EMPLOYEES IN THE AREA OF THE 
IMPAIRMENT SHALL BE PROVIDED WITH INFORMATION ON ALTERNATE FIRE PROTECTION THAT 
WILL BE AVAILABLE. 
D. THE SUSPENSION OF ALL NON -ESSENTIAL HOT WORK PERMITS UNTIL THE CONCLUSION AND 
REACTIVATION OF THE PRE -ACTION FIRE SUPPRESSION SYSTEM AND INTERFACING FIRE 
DETECTION SYSTEM. 
2. FIRE PROTECTION IMPAIRMENT PLAN 
A. A FIRE PROTECTION IMPAIRMENT PLAN SHOULD BE DEVELOPED AND IMPLEMENTED BEFORE 
AUTHORIZATION IS GIVEN, THE IMPAIRMENT COORDINATOR SHOULD VERIFY THAT THE 
FOLLOWING PROCEDURES HAVE BEEN IMPLEMENTED: 
• THE EXTENT AND EXPECTED DURATION OF THE IMPAIRMENT THAT HAS BEEN DETERMINED. 
• THE AREA OF THE BUILDING THAT WILL BE AFFECTED HAS BEEN INSPECTED AND THE 
INCREASED RISKS DETERMINED. 
• RECOMMENDATIONS HAVE BEEN SUBMITTED TO THE ARCHITECT, ENGINEER AND OWNER 
OR OWNER'S REPRESENTATIVE TO MITIGATE ANY INCREASED RISKS. 
• WHERE A REQUIRED FIRE PROTECTION SYSTEM IS OUT OF SERVICE FOR MORE THAN TEN 
HOURS IN A 24 HOUR PERIOD THE CONTRACTOR & OWNER SHALL ARRANGE FOR THE 
FOLLOWING: 
• AN APPROVED FIRE WATCH. 
• ESTABLISHMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF AN APPROVED PROGRAM TO ELIMINATE 
POTENTIAL IGNITION SOURCES AND LIMIT OF THE AMOUNT OF COMBUSTIBLES IN THE 
AREA OF CONSTRUCTION. 
• ASSIGN PERSONNEL TO TRANSMIT FIRE ALARMS TO THE OWNER'S HOSPITAL 
COORDINATOR WHERE THE MAIN FIRE ALARM PANEL IS BEING MONITORED FOR 24/7 
COVERAGE. 
3. TAG IMPAIRMENT SYSTEM 
A. A TAG SHALL BE USED TO INDICATE THAT A SYSTEM OR PART THERE OF, HAS BEEN REMOVED 
FROM SERVICE. THE CONTRACTOR SHALL PLACE TAGS ON ALL AFFECTED COMPONENTS, E.G., 
TAMPER SWITCHES, VALVES, FIRE ALARM ANNUNICATOR DEVICES, ETC., PRIOR TO THE 
COMMENCEMENT OF ANY WORK. 
B. THE TAG SHALL BE POSTED AT EACH FIRE PROTECTION CONNECTION AND SYSTEM CONTROL 
VALVE AND OTHER LOCATION REQUIRED BY THE OWNER'S REPRESENTATIVE OR ANY AND ALL 
AUTHORITIES HAVING JURISDICTION, INDICATING WHICH SYSTEM, OR PART THERE OF, HAS 
BEEN REMOVED FROM SERVICE. 
• THE SUPERVISORS IN THE AREA TO THE AFFECTED AREA HAS BEEN NOTIFIED. 
• THE FIRE DEPARTMENT HAS BEEN NOTIFIED. 
• A TAG IMPAIRMENT SYSTEM HAVE BEEN IMPLEMENTED. 
• ALL NECESSARY TOOLS, EQUIPMENT, MATERIAL AND APPURTENANCES ARE LOCATED AND 
ASSEMBLED ON THE IMPAIRMENT SITE. 
4. RESTORING SYSTEMS TO SERVICE 
A. WHEN ALL IMPAIRED EQUIPMENT IS RESTORED TO NORMAL WORKING ORDER, THE ARCHITECT/ 
ENGINEER SHALL VERIFY THAT THE CONTRACTOR HAS IMPLEMENTED THE FOLLOWING 
PROCEDURES: 
• ALL NECESSARY INSPECTION HAVE BEEN CONDUCTED FOLLOWING NFPA 13, 25 AND 72 
REQUIREMENTS IN ORDER TO VERIFY THAT THE AFFECTED SYSTEM ARE OPERATION. 
CONTRACTOR SHALL SUBMIT ALL REQUIRED RECORDS AND RECORDS SHALL INDICATE THE 
PROCEDURE PERFORMED, THE ORGANIZATION THAT PERFORMED THE WORK, RESULTS 
AND THE DATE. 
• OPEN ALL VALVES THAT WERE SECURED DURING THE IMPAIRMENT. 
• REMOVE IMPAIRMENT TAG ONCE VALVES ARE OPEN. 
• CONDUCT A DRAIN TEST IN THE WIDE OPEN POSITION. 
• ENSURE THE FIRE PROTECTION SYSTEM IS PLACED BACK TO "AUTOMATIC" SERVICE. 
• RESET FIRE ALARM SYSTEM AND NOTIFY OWNER'S REPRESENTATIVE AND FIRE ALARM 
COMPANY THAT MONITORS THE OWNER'S MAIN FIRE ALARM PANEL ON 24/7 COVERAGE. 
• ARCHITECT, ENGINEER AND OWNERS REPRESENTATIVE HAVE BEEN ADVISED THAT THE 
FIRE PROTECTION AND FIRE DETECTION SYSTEM THAT WAS IMPAIRED HAS BEEN 
RESTORED. 
• THE OWNER'S REPRESENTATIVE OR DESIGNATED REPRESENTATIVE, FIRE ALARM COMPANY 
WHO MONITORS THE MAIN FIRE ALARM PANEL FOR 24/7 COVERAGE AND ALL OTHER 
JURISDICTIONS HAVE BEEN ADVISED THAT BOTH FIRE PROTECTION SYSTEMS IS RESTORED. 
• THE IMPAIRMENT TAG HAS BEEN REMOVED. 
• COORDINATE ALL PROCEDURES WITH VA CONTRACTING OFFICER REPRESENTATIVE AND 
DESIGNATED FIRE SAFETY OFFICIAL. 
PROCEDURES FOR IMPAIRMENT TO THE FIRE PROTECTION 
SYSTEM 
FIRE WATCH PROCEDURES AND REQUIREMENTS 
A. THE FIRE ALARM CONTRACTOR'S FIRE WATCH PERSONNEL SHALL BE TRAINED TO UNDERSTAND THE 
INHERENT HAZARDS OF THE WORK SITE AND OF THE HOT WORK TO OCCUR. 
B. THE FIRE ALARM CONTRACTOR'S FIRE WATCH SHALL ENSURE THAT SAFE CONDITIONS ARE MAINTAINED 
DURING OUTAGE OF THE FIRE ALARM/FIRE SUPPRESSION SYSTEM AND/OR DURING THE 
OCCURRENCE OF HOT WORK OPERATION. 
C. THE FIRE ALARM CONTRACTOR'S FIRE WATCH SHALL HAVE THE AUTHORITY TO STOP HOT WORK 
OPERATIONS IF UNSAFE OPERATIVE DEVELOPS. 
D. THE FIRE ALARM CONTRACTOR'S FIRE WATCH SHALL HAVE FIRE EXTINGUISHING EQUIPMENT 
READILY AVAILABLE AND TRAINED IN ITS USE, E.G., FIRE EXTINGUISHERS. 
E. THE FIRE ALARM CONTRACTOR'S FIRE WATCH SHALL BE FAMILIAR WITH OWNER'S FACILITIES AND 
PROCEDURES FOR SOUNDING AN ALARM IN THE EVENT OF A FIRE. 
F. THE FIRE ALARM CONTRACTOR'S FIRE WATCH SHALL WATCH FOR FIRES IN ALL EXPOSED AREAS 
AND TRY TO EXTINGUISH A FIRE ONLY WHEN THE FIRES ARE OBVIOUSLY WITHIN THE CAPACITY OF THE 
AVAILABLE EXTINGUISHING EQUIPMENT. IF THE FIRE ALARM CONTRACTOR'S FIRE WATCH DETERMINES 
THAT THE FIRE IS NOT WITHIN THE CAPACITY OF THE EQUIPMENT THE FIRE WATCH SHALL SOUND AN 
ALARM IMMEDIATELY (E.G.,INITIATE A MANUALLY ACTUATED ALARM INDICATING DEVICE THAT IS 
OUTSIDE OF THE CONSTRUCTION AREA DURING THE DISRUPTION OF THE FIRE ALARM/DETECTION 
WITHIN THE CONSTRUCTION WORK SCOPE OR WITHIN THE CONSTRUCTION WORK SCOPE IF THE FIRE 
ALARM/DETECTION SYSTEM HAS BEEN ACTIVATED). 
G. BEFORE STARTING ANY HOT WORK, THE CONTRACTORS AND THEIR OWNERS SHALL DISCUSS THE 
PLANNED PROJECT COMPLETELY INCLUDING THE TYPE OF HOT WORK TO BE CONDUCTED AND THE 
HAZARDS IN THE AREA WITH THE ASSOCIATED PLAN OF ACTION, IN ORDER, TO PROVIDE EQUIVALENT 
SAFETY MEASURES TAKEN DURING THE FIRE DETECTION OR FIRE SUPPRESSION IMPAIRMENT. 
FIRE ALARM GENERAL NOTES - DEMOLITION 
1. THE INTENTS OF THE DEMOLITION ON THIS PROJECT IS FOR REMOVAL/REWORK OF THE EXISTING FIRE ALARM 
SYSTEM REQUIRED FOR THE INSTALLATION OF NEW DEVICES. REMOVAL SHALL INCLUDE WIRE, EXPOSED 
RACEWAYS, FIRE ALARM EQUIPMENT & ASSOCIATED DEVICES, SUPPORTING DEVICES AND ANY OTHER 
MISCELLANEOUS EQUIPMENT ASSOCIATED WITH THE FIRE ALARM SYSTEM.  
2. THE DEMOLITION OF THE FIRE ALARM SYSTEM MUST BE PHASED. NEW AND EXISTING FIRE ALARM DEVICES 
AND SYSTEMS MUST BE INTERCONNECTED TO PROVIDE SIMULTANEOUS ACTIVATION AND NOTIFICATION.  
EXISTING FIRE ALARM SYSTEMS SHALL BE TREATED AS SEPARATE ADDRESSES ON THE NEW SYSTEM UNTIL 
THEY ARE REMOVED OR REPLACED. 
3. THE FIRE ALARM CONTRACTOR IS RESPONSIBLE FOR, BUT NOT LIMITED TO: ALL TEMPORARY AND 
PERMANENT CROSSOVER CONNECTIONS, RELOCATION OF SYSTEM EQUIPMENT AND REPROGRAMMING OF 
THE SYSTEM AND EQUIPMENT TO THE NEW AND EXISTING FIRE ALARM SYSTEM.  
RENOVATION/CONSTRUCTION FOR THIS SCOPE OF WORK SHALL INCLUDE BUT NOT LIMITED TO THE 
FOLLOWING SYSTEMS: 
A. NORMAL POWER/LIGHTING CIRCUITS 
B. EMERGENCY POWER/LIGHTING CIRCUITS 
C. FIRE ALARM SYSTEMS 
D. TELEPHONE SYSTEMS 
E. DATA SYSTEMS.  
4. OWNER RETAINS RIGHTS OF SALVAGE FOR EQUIPMENT AND FIXTURES TO BE REMOVED. COORDINATE WITH 
THE OWNER THE EQUIPMENT AND FIXTURES TO BE SALVAGED AND THE LOCATION FOR STORAGE.  AVOID 
DAMAGE TO EQUIPMENT, FIXTURES AND DEVICES DURING DEMOLITION WORK AND DURING TRANSPORT TO 
OWNER ’S DESIGNATED STORAGE LOCATION. 
5. THE DEMOLITION PLAN IS NOT INCLUSIVE OF ALL ELECTRICAL DEVICES, FITTINGS, CONDUITS, ETC., IT IS 
INTENDED TO PROVIDE THE CONTRACTOR WITH A GENERAL KNOWLEDGE OF EXISTING CONDITIONS WITHIN 
THE PROJECT AREA. 
6. THE FIRE ALARM CONTRACTOR SHALL BE RESPONSIBLE TO SUPPORT ALL EXISTING FIRE ALARM EQUIPMENT, 
SYSTEM WIRING AND CABLES THAT ARE TO REMAIN WHEN EXISTING CEILINGS ARE REMOVED AND REPLACED. 
PROVIDE THE APPROPRIATE LISTED INDUSTRY RECOGNIZED SUPPORTS FOR ALL APPLICATIONS.  
7. ALL WORK SHALL BE PERFORMED SO AS TO NOT INTERRUPT SERVICE TO THE ENTIRE AFFECTED BUILDING. 
THE CONTRACTOR SHALL PROPERLY NOTIFY THE BUILDING OWNER AS APPLICABLE WITH A MINIMUM NOTICE 
OF 48 HOURS IN ADVANCE BEFORE PROCEEDING WITH THIS WORK. 
8. REMOVE ALL UNUSED AND DEMOLISHED EQUIPMENT AND ASSOCIATED MATERIAL FROM THE SITE.  
ABANDONING UNUSED PORTIONS WILL NOT BE ACCEPTABLE. 
9. AVOID DAMAGING EXISTING SURFACES AND EQUIPMENT AND ASSOCIATED MATERIALS FROM THE SITE.  
REPAIR ANY DAMAGE CAUSED DURING WORK AT NO EXTRA COST TO THE OWNER. 
10. REPAIR FIRE AND SMOKE RATED PARTITIONS SURROUNDING FIRE ALARM WORK AS SPECIFIED. REFER TO 
ARCHITECTURE PLANS FOR LOCATIONS OF SMOKE AND FIRE PARTITIONS.  
11. THE FIRE ALARM CONTRACTOR IS RESPONSIBLE FOR ALL CONDUIT PENETRATIONS THROUGH CHASES, 
WALLS, FLOORS OR CEILING WHICH ARE FIRE -RATED. THE FIRE ALARM CONTRACTOR SHALL UNDER THE 
DIRECTION OF THE ARCHITECT, PROPERLY SEAL ALL PENETRATIONS TO MAINTAIN FIRE PROTECTION RATING. 
ALL PIPING PENETRATIONS MUST BE SEALED IN ACCORDANCE WITH “UL ” LISTING SEALING METHOD AND/OR 
AS DETAILED IN THESE CONTRACT DOCUMENTS AND SPECIFICATIONS. REPAIR SURFACES TO MATCH 
ADJACENT AREAS. REFER TO ARCHITECTURE PLANS FOR LOCATIONS OF SMOKE AND FIRE PARTITIONS. 
12. ALL CUTTING AND PATCHING, RELOCATING OF ANY EQUIPMENT, LIGHT FIXTURES, CONDUITS, PIPING, ETC., 
NECESSARY TO PERFORM THE WORK WILL BE THE FIRE ALARM CONTRACTOR ’S RESPONSIBILITY UNLESS 
NOTED OTHERWISE. ALL AFFECTED SURFACES WILL BE RESTORED TO THEIR ORIGINAL CONDITION. 
13. REMOVE ANY CEILING TILES, GRID, AND LIGHT FIXTURES REQUIRED TO ACCOMPLISH THE WORK. REPLACE 
SAME AFTER THE INSTALLATION IS COMPLETE. IT IS THE FIRE ALARM CONTRACTOR ’S RESPONSIBILITY TO 
REPLACE ANY ITEMS DAMAGED DURING CONSTRUCTION. 
14. THE FIRE ALARM CONTRACTOR SHALL FIELD VERIFY ALL EXISTING ELECTRICAL & FIRE ALARM LINES, 
PLUMBING LINES, DUCTWORK OR MECHANICAL PIPING LOCATED IN THE CEILING SPACE, WALLS OR FLOOR 
PRIOR TO SAW CUTTING OR ANY CORE DRILLING. IT IS THE CONTRACTOR ’S RESPONSIBILITY TO REPAIR SUCH 
ITEMS DAMAGED. 
15. THE FIRE ALARM CONTRACTOR SHALL PATCH, PAINT AND MATCH FINISH WITH EXISTING SURFACES TO 
REMAIN WHERE FIRE ALARM DEVICES ARE BEING REMOVED. 
16. THE BUILDING WILL BE IN OPERATION DURING THE DEMOLITION AND CONSTRUCTION. CONTRACTOR SHALL 
REFER TO PHASING PLAN AND NOTIFY OWNER A MINIMUM OF 48 HOURS PRIOR TO DISCONNECTION OF 
EXISTING FIRE ALARM SIGNALING AND MONITORING SYSTEM. 
17. BEFORE DEMOLITION OF ANY FIRE ALARM CONDUIT, WIRING OR CIRCUIT THE FIRE ALARM CONTRACTOR 
SHALL VERIFY ALL CIRCUITS BEING SERVED OUTSIDE THE CONSTRUCTION AREA ARE OPERATIONAL.  VERIFY 
WITH OWNER BEFORE DISRUPTING THE EXISTING FIRE ALARM SERVICES WHICH MAY HAVE AN AFFECT ON 
FIRE ALARM DEVICES OUTSIDE THE CONSTRUCTION AREA. ANY EXISTING FIRE ALARM DEVICES DISRUPTED 
BY THE DEMOLITION ARE TO BE RESTORED TO OPERATION IMMEDIATELY OR WITH THE TIME AGREED UPON 
WITH THE VA COR.  
18. VERIFY THAT EXISTING EQUIPMENT, I.E., TAMPER SWITCHES, WATER FLOW SWITCHES, ETC., TO REMAIN IS 
OPERATING PROPERLY. NOTIFY THE ARCHITECT, ENGINEER AND VA COR, AND VA FIRE SAFETY OFFICIAL OF 
ANY DAMAGED AND/OR MALFUNCTIONING COMPONENTS.   
19. COORDINATE FIRE ALARM SYSTEM MODIFICATIONS TO MINIMIZE SYSTEM IMPAIRMENT. THE FIRE ALARM 
CONTRACTOR SHALL PROVIDE FIRE WATCH AND INTERIM FIRE PROTECTION MEASURES WHERE REQUIRED 
BY THE VA COR, VA FIRE OFFICIAL, THESE CONTRACT DOCUMENTS AND BOOK SPECIFICATION DOCUMENTS.  
20. IT SHALL BE THE RESPONSIBILITY OF THE FIRE ALARM CONTRACTOR TO REMOVE AND LEGALLY DISPOSE OF 
DEMOLISHED MATERIALS.  
21. THE VA RESERVES THE RIGHT TO INSPECT THE MATERIAL SCHEDULED FOR REMOVAL AND SALVAGE ANY 
ITEMS DEEMED USEABLE AS SPARE PARTS.  
22. REFER TO DEMOLITION DRAWINGS FOR FURTHER DEMOLITION INFORMATION. THE FIRE ALARM CONTRACTOR 
SHALL REMOVE ASSOCIATED FIRE ALARM DEVICES, EQUIPMENT OR ACCESSORIES OF EXISTING SYSTEM TO 
BE REMOVED. 
23. WHERE INDICATED ON PLANS, THE FIRE ALARM CONTRACTOR IS RESPONSIBLE FOR REMOVING ALL 
PORTIONS OF ABANDONED FIRE ALARM CABLE AND CONDUIT IN ACCORDANCE WITH NFPA 70.

FIRE ALARM GENERAL NOTES - NEW 
A. REFER TO DRAWING FA001 FOR FIRE ALARM GENERAL NOTES, ABBREVIATIONS AND SYMBOLS. 
B. REFER TO FA003 FOR FIRE ALARM INPUT / OUTPUT MATRIX. ALL FIRE ALARM DEVICES SHALL BE INTERFACED 
WITH THE EXISTING FIRE ALARM SYSTEM AND PROGRAMMING OF THE NEW POINTS AT THE LOCAL AND MAIN 
FIRE ALARM CONTROL PANELS.. 
C. REFER TO DRAWING FX004 FOR TEMPORARY FIRE ALARM, FIRE EXTINGUISHER AND FIRE SUPPRESSION 
REQUIREMENTS DURING AN IMPAIRMENT TO THE EXISTING SYSTEM. 
D. REFER TO DRAWING FX004 FOR IMPAIRMENT REQUIREMENTS AND PROCEDURES THAT SHALL BE MET BY THE 
CONTRACTOR PRIOR TO THE REMOVAL AND/OR DEACTIVATION OF ANY FIRE DETECTION DEVICE. 
E. THE INFORMATION GIVEN HEREIN IS AS EXACT AS COULD BE SECURED FOR BIDDING PURPOSES AND ITS 
ACCURACY IS NOT GUARANTEED. THE FIRE ALARM CONTRACTOR IS RESPONSIBLE FOR EXAMINING NEW JOB 
CONDITIONS AND VERIFYING ALL MEASUREMENTS, DISTANCES, ELEVATIONS, CLEARANCES, PIPE SIZES, ETC., 
BEFORE STARTING THE DEMOLITION OR NEW WORK. 
F. THE DRAWING SHALL NOT BE SCALED FOR CONSTRUCTION PURPOSES. THE SCALE WHEN INDICATED FOR 
GENERAL REFERENCE ONLY. 
G. ALL ALARMS, SUPERVISORY AND DETECTION SYSTEMS SHALL BE CONNECTED TO THE NEW BUILDING FIRE 
ALARM CONTROL PANEL AND THIS PANEL SHALL BE INTERFACED WITH THE HOSPITAL MAIN FIRE ALARM 
PANEL FOR 24/7 REMOTE MONITORING STATION. 
H. ANY EXISTING OR NEW PIPE OR DUCTWORK INSULATION THAT IS DAMAGED DURING CONSTRUCTION SHALL 
BE REMOVED AND REPLACED WITH NEW INSULATION TO MATCH ADJACENT INSULATION AND COVERING AT 
THE FIRE ALARM CONTRACTOR'S EXPENSE. 
I. VISUAL NOTIFICATION APPLIANCE SHALL BE LOCATED NOT MORE THAN 15 FEET FROM THE END OF A 
CORRIDOR WITH A SEPARATION NOT GREATER THAN 100 FEET BETWEEN APPLIANCES. 
J. COORDINATE FIRE ALARM ZONES WITH SMOKE COMPARTMENTS AND SPRINKLER ZONES. 
K. MANUAL FIRE ALARM PULL STATIONS SHALL BE LOCATED WITHIN 60 INCHES OF EACH EXIT DOORWAY. 
L. FOR EACH GROUP OF ELEVATORS, PROVIDE A NORMALLY CLOSED CONTACT REPRESENTING THE SMOKE 
DETECTOR AT THE DESIGNATED LANDING. 
M. THE FIRE ALARM CONTRACTOR SHALL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR FIELD VERIFYING  EXISTING CONDITIONS PRIOR 
TO CONSTRUCTION. THE EXISTING FIRE ALARM EQUIPMENT ABOVE CEILING AND WITHIN WALLS WILL NEED TO 
BE FIELD VERIFIED. 
N. THE EXISTING BUILDING'S LOCAL FIRE ALARM CONTROL PANEL(S) SHALL REMAIN IN SERVICE AT ALL TIMES 
THROUGHOUT THE RENOVATION AREAS SHOWN ON THESE CONTRACT DOCUMENTS; SPECIAL PROVISIONS 
SHALL BE MADE BETWEEN THE FIRE ALARM CONTRACTOR AND THE ARCHITECT, THE ENGINEER AND THE 
COR'S REPRESENTATIVE TO DISCONNECT POWER TO THE AREAS OF THE RENOVATION TO MINIMIZE THE 
INTERRUPTIONS IN THE FIRE ALARM SERVICE. 
O. VERIFY THAT EXISTING EQUIPMENT, I.E., TAMPER SWITCHES, WATER FLOW SWITCHES, ETC., TO REMAIN IS 
OPERATING PROPERLY. NOTIFY THE ARCHITECT, ENGINEER AND VA COR OF ANY DAMAGED AND/OR 
MALFUNCTIONING COMPONENTS.   
P. COORDINATE FIRE ALARM SYSTEM MODIFICATIONS TO MINIMIZE SYSTEM IMPAIRMENT. PROVIDE FIRE WATCH 
AND INTERIM FIRE PROTECTION MEASURES WHERE REQUIRED BY THE AUTHORITY HAVING JURISDICTION OR 
THE COR. 
Q. FIRE DETECTION CONTRACTOR SHALL PROVIDE ABOVE AND BELOW ALL OBSTRUCTIONS COMPLYING WITH 
NFPA 72. 
R. UPON ACTIVATION OF FIRE ALARM RELEASE ALL DOORS ON MAGNETIC HOLD OPEN WITHIN THE SPECIFIC 
SMOKE ZONE SHALL CLOSE. REFER TO FA -004 FIRE ALARM INPUT/OUTPUT MATRIX. 
S. THE CONTRACTOR SHALL ADHERE TO THE SEPARATION DISTANCES BETWEEN SPEAKER STROBES SHOWN 
ON THESE CONTRACT DRAWINGS; SINCE, PER THE VA FIRE PROTECTION DESIGN MANUAL (FPDM) SECTION 
7.3.F(2)(k) THE VA FPDM CLEARLY STATES THAT " SPEAKERS MUST BE INSTALLED AND ARRANGED SO THEY 
ARE CLEARLY HEARD AND UNDERSTOOD BY STAFF UNDER NORMAL WORKING CONDITIONS. SPEAKER 
LAYOUT IS TO INSTALL THEM EVERY TWENTY -FIVE ON CENTER AND NOT TO EXPECT THEM TO CLEARLY 
HEARD THROUGH MORE THAN ONE WALL." 
S. ALL DUCT SMOKE DETECTORS LOCATED IN THE HVAC SYSTEM SHALL BE INSTALLED BY THE MECHANICAL 
CONTRACTOR; AND ALL FIRE ALARM INTERFACE, BETWEEN THE DUCT SMOKE DETECTOR AND THE MAIN FIRE 
ALARM CONTROL PANEL, IS THE RESPONSIBILITY OF THE FIRE DETECTION CONTRACTOR/INSTALLER. 
T. CONNECT DUCT SMOKE DETECTOR IN THE HVAC SYSTEM TO ACTIVATE THE FIRE ALARM SYSTEM AND 
SHUTDOWN OF THE HVAC SYSTEM IN THE EVENT OF SMOKE DETECTED WITHIN THE DUCTS. 
U. FURNISH AND INSTALL DUCT SMOKE DETECTOR TEST STATIONS IN THE CEILING TO SHOW LOCATIONS OF 
DETECTOR WHEN IN ALARM OR TROUBLE INDICATION. 
V. FIRE/SMOKE DAMPERS SHALL BE PROVIDED AND INSTALLED BY THE MECHANICAL CONTRACTOR AND ALL 
FIRE ALARM INTERFACES BETWEEN THE FIRE/SMOKE  DAMPER AND THE MAIN FIRE ALARM CONTROL PANEL 
IS THE RESPONSIBILITY OF THE FIRE ALARM CONTRACTOR/INSTALLER. 
W. VISUAL NOTIFICATION APPLIANCE SHALL BE LOCATED NOT MORE THAN 15 FEET FROM THE END OF A 
CORRIDOR. 
X. UPON ACTIVATION OF FIRE ALARM RELEASE ALL DOORS ON MAGNETIC HOLD OPEN WITHIN THE SPECIFIC 
SMOKE ZONE SHALL CLOSE. REFER TO FA -003 FIRE ALARM INPUT/OUTPUT MATRIX . 
Y. VA ATLANTA HOSPITAL WILL REQUIRE THAT THE EXISTING NOTIFICATION DEVICES AND TEMPORARY HEAT 
DETECTORS SPECIFIED ON FA003 SHALL BE IN PLACE AND PROGRAMMED AT THE TWO MAIN FIRE ALARM 
CONTROL PANEL AT THE POLICE DISPATCH, TELEPHONE OPERATOR PBX AND THE ONYX COMPUTER SYSTEM 
WITHIN THE BOILER ROOM.  EACH AND EVERY NODE, FIFTEEN IN TOTAL WILL NEED TO BE UPDATED ONCE THE 
HEAT DETECTORS ARE ADDED TO NODES 9 & 10.  AN ACTIVE FIRE ALARM AND DETECTION SYSTEM MUST BE 
IN PLACE BEFORE REMOVAL AND RELOCATION OF ANY FIRE ALARM DEVICE. THEREFORE, IT IS 
RECOMMENDED THAT DURING THE NEW WORK ON THE SIXTH FLOOR THE LAST ITEMS TO BE MOVED SHOULD 
BE THE EXISTING FIRE ALARM NOTIFICATION AND DETECTION DEVICES. THE NEW NOTIFICATION, INITIATING 
DEVICES MUST BE PROGRAMMED AND ACCEPTED BY THE VA AND ENGINEER OF RECORD PRIOR TO 
RELOCATION OF THE EXISTING SMOKE DETECTORS AND SPEAKER -STROBE NOTIFICATION DEVICES. 
THEREFORE, THERE WILL BE TWO ROUNDS OF TESTING AND ACCEPTANCE, E.G., PRE TESTING OF ALL NEW 
DEVICES AND FINAL TESTING OF THE NEW AND EXISTING DEVICES IN ORDER TO VALIDATE AND 
CERTIFICATION OF APPROVAL OF THE SYSTEM RECORD OF COMPLETION SHOWN IN NFPA 72, FIGURE 7.8.2. 
Z. THE VA ATLANTA HOSPITAL REQUIREMENTS FOR A SHUTDOWN IS THAT NO FIRE ALARM SYSTEM SHALL BE 
DISCONNECTED FOR MORE THAN 4 HOURS. APPROVALS OF ANY FIRE ALARM SHUTDOWN IS TO BE 
SUBMITTED AND APPROVED TO THE VA CHIEF ENGINEER, THE VA FIRE SAFETY OFFICIAL THE VA COR AND THE 
ENGINEER OF RECORD WITH DETAILED SCHEDULE CHRONICALLY ORDER OF WORK SCOPE TO BE 
COMPLETED BETWEEN START AND FINISH OF THE FIRE ALARM SHUTDOWN.

CARD READERS BEING PROVIDED SHALL BE INTERFACED WITH THE POWER AND FIRE ALARM SYSTEM. ALL ACCESS

FIRE PROTECTION GENERAL NOTES 
1. THE NEW SPRINKLER SYSTEM SHALL BE SIZED IN ACCORDANCE WITH NFPA 13 AND SHALL BE 
HYDRAULICALLY CALCULATED TO MEET THE REQUIREMENTS OF NFPA 13, NFPA 101 AND THE VA FIRE 
PROTECTION DESIGN MANUAL, AND APPROVED BY VA COR, VA FIRE OFFICAL AND THE ENGINEER OF 
RECORD. THE CONTRACTOR SHALL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR PROVIDING FLOW TEST DATA TO PERFORM 
AS A BASIS OF THEIR CALCULATIONS. 
2. THE SYSTEM SHALL BE DESIGNED AND BUILT IN A WORKMANLIKE MANNER, IN ACCORDANCE WITH 
DETAILED DRAWINGS TO BE SUBMITTED FOR APPROVAL. THE WORK SHALL INCLUDE ALL COMPONENTS 
REQUIRED TO PROVIDE A COMPLETE SYSTEM.  
3. THE FIRE PROTECTION CONTRACTOR SHALL PROVIDE A SET OF SHOP DRAWINGS THAT INCLUDE ALL 
PIPE SIZES, ELEVATIONS, HEAD LOCATIONS, DIMENSIONS, VALVES, INSPECTOR TESTS, FLOW SWITCHES, 
TAMPER SWITCHES, ETC.  
4. THE FIRE PROTECTION CONTRACTOR SHALL PROVIDE SPRINKLER LAYOUT INCLUDING LOCATION OF 
PENDANT HEADS FOR ALL LOCATION IN THIS SCOPE OF WORK.  
5. THE SHOP DRAWINGS AND CALCULATIONS SHALL BE SUBMITTED TO VA COR ’ S ENGINEER AND THESE 
CALCULATIONS AND DRAWINGS SHALL BE SUBMITTED TO VA FIRE OFFICIAL.  
6. SPRINKLER HEADS AND ASSOCIATED MAIN/BRANCH PIPING SHALL BE PROVIDED AND LOCATED IN 
ACCORDANCE WITH NFPA 13 AND VA FIRE PROTECTION DESIGN MANUAL REQUIREMENTS. IT IS THE 
CONTRACTOR ’ S RESPONSIBILITY TO CONFIRM LOCATIONS FOR COMPLIANCE WITH THE CODE 
REQUIREMENTS.  
7. THE FIRE PROTECTION CONTRACTOR SHALL VERIFY ALL EXISTING CONDITIONS AT THE PROJECT SITE. 
8. SPRINKLER PIPING SHOULD BE ROUTED AS HIGH AS POSSIBLE WHILE STILL COORDINATING WITH OTHER 
TRADES. ELEVATION OF SPRINKLER PIPING AND HEAD MUST BE DETERMINED BY PROPOSED OR 
EXISTING CEILING HEIGHTS.  
9. ALL MATERIAL AND ITS INSTALLATION SHALL BE IN COMPLETE COMPLIANCE WITH ALL APPLICABLE 
SECTIONS OF THE LATEST EDITION OF NFPA. AND FACTORY MUTUAL GUIDELINES. THE FIRE PROTECTION 
CONTRACTOR SHALL BE REQUIRED TO COMPLY WITH ALL SPECIAL CONDITIONS SET FORTH BY THE 
INSURANCE UNDERWRITER IF AND WHEN REQUIRED BY THE COR.  
10. THE FIRE PROTECTION CONTRACTOR SHALL FURNISH ALL LABOR, MATERIAL AND EQUIPMENT; AND, 
PERFORM ALL OPERATIONS NECESSARY FOR THE INSTALLATION OF A COMPLETE FIRE PROTECTION 
SYSTEM THAT IS READY FOR USE WITHIN THE INTENT OF AND AS INDICATED ON THE DRAWINGS, 
SPECIFICATIONS AND AS HEREIN SPECIFIED.  
11. PROVIDE CUTTING AND PATCHING OF BUILDING AS REQUIRED TO INSTALL NEW WORK.  
12. SMALL ITEMS NOT SHOWN OR SPECIFIED, BUT OBVIOUSLY REQUIRED BY GOOD GENERAL PRACTICE TO 
COMPLETE THE WORK SHALL BE FURNISHED AND INSTALLED THE SAME AS IF BOTH SHOWN AND 
SPECIFIED.  
13. BY SUBMITTING A PROPOSAL FOR THIS WORK, THE CONTRACTOR WILL BE HELD TO HAVE EXAMINED THE 
SITE AND SATISFIED THEMSELVES AS TO EXISTING CONDITIONS UNDER WHICH THEY WILL BE OBLIGED 
TO OPERATE OR THAT WILL IN ANY MANNER AFFECT THEIR WORK UNDER THIS CONTRACT.  NO 
ALLOWANCES SHALL BE MADE SUBSEQUENTLY IN THIS CONTRACT IN BEHALF OF CONTRACTOR OF ANY 
ERROR OR NEGLIGENCE ON THEIR PART.  
14. FIRE PROTECTION CONTRACTOR SHALL MAKE CONNECTION INTO THE EXISTING FIRE SUPPRESSION  
WATER MAIN. 
15. THE FIRE PROTECTION CONTRACTOR SHALL NOTIFY THE VA FIRE MARSHAL, THE ENGINEER, THE 
ARCHITECT, CONTRACTOR AND GENERAL CONTRACTOR ONE WEEK PRIOR TO ANY SHUTDOWNS OR 
INTERRUPTIONS OF SERVICE. 
16. WHERE SO INDICATED ON THE PLANS AS PART OF THE PROJECT SCOPE OF WORK, THE FIRE 
PROTECTION CONTRACTOR SHALL MAKE CONNECTION INTO THE EXISTING FIRE SERVICE WATER 
SYSTEM.  
17. THE FIRE PROTECTION CONTRACTOR SHALL SCHEDULE WITH THE VA COR ALL TIE -INS TO EXISTING 
SYSTEMS AND PERFORM REQUIRED SHUTDOWN AND RE -INITIALIZATION OF THE EXISTING FIRE 
SPRINKLER SYSTEM; THESE SERVICES WILL INCLUDE DRAIN AND REFILL OF THE FIRE SPRINKLER 
SYSTEMS IN THE AFFECTED AREAS OF THIS PROJECT WORK SCOPE.  
18. ALL FIRE PROTECTION WORK SHALL BE MADE IN ACCORDANCE WITH RULES AND REGULATIONS OF THE 
VA FIRE PROTECTION DESIGN MANUAL, NFPA 13 , NFPA 25 AND NFPA 101. THE ENTIRE FIRE PROTECTION 
SYSTEM FOR THE WORK SCOPE SHOWN ON THESE DESIGN DRAWINGS SHALL BE MADE BY THIS 
CONTRACTOR IN THE PRESENCE OF THE VA COR, VA FIRE OFFICAL AND THE ENGINEER OF RECORD. THE 
FIRE PROTECTION SYSTEM SHALL BE TESTED  AS REQUIRED BY NFPA 13 AND NFPA 25.  
19. THROUGH PENETRATION ASSEMBLIES SHALL BE PROVIDED AT EACH OPENING WHERE EXPOSED 
SPRINKLER PIPING PASS THROUGH RATED WALLS, FLOORS AND PARTITIONS. ALL PIPING PENETRATIONS 
MUST BE SEALED IN ACCORDANCE WITH “ UL ”  LISTING SEALING METHOD AND/OR AS DETAILED IN THESE 
CONTRACT DRAWINGS OR SPECIFICATIONS.  
20. ALL APPLIANCES AND APPURTENANCES SHALL BEAR LABEL OF UL/FM APPROVED AND LABELED FOR ITS 
INTENDED USE. 
21. ALL MATERIALS AND EQUIPMENT SHALL BE INSTALLED AND COMPLETED IN A FIRST -CLASS 
WORKMANLIKE MANNER AND IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE BEST MODERN METHODS AND PRACTICES.  
ANY MATERIALS WHICH SHALL NOT PRESENT AN ORDERLY AND REASONABLY NEAT AND/OR 
WORKMANLIKE APPEARANCE SHALL BE REMOVED AND REPLACED WHEN SO DIRECTED BY THE 
ARCHITECT OR ENGINEER OF RECORD. THE REMOVAL AND REPLACEMENT OF THIS WORK SHALL BE 
DONE WHEN DIRECTED IN WRITING BY THE ARCHITECT, AT THE CONTRACTOR ’ S EXPENSE.  
22. ALL HANGERS SHALL BE FASTENED BY MEANS OF BEAM CLAMPS, CONCRETE INSERTS OR OTHER 
APPROVED DEVICES INSTALLED BY THIS CONTRACTOR.  
23. SPRINKLER HEAD RATINGS, SPRAY TYPE, AND FINISH SHALL BE AS SPECIFIED ON PROJECT PLANS. 
WHERE NOT SPECIFICALLY IDENTIFIED ON PLANS, SPRINKLER HEADS SHALL QUICK RESPONSE TYPE 
UPRIGHT PENDANT WITH PAINTED COVER PLATE OR AS REQUIRED BY THE COR. REGULAR PENDANT 
HEADS IN FINISHED SPACES SHALL BE CHROME PLATED WITH CHROME PLATED CEILING PLATES UNLESS 
OTHERWISE NOTED. NEW HEADS SHALL MATCH EXISTING.  
24. THE FIRE PROTECTION CONTRACTOR WILL BE REQUIRED TO COORDINATE ACCEPTANCE FOR VARIATION 
OF EQUIPMENT LOCATIONS AND EQUIPMENT CONFIGURATIONS WITH THE COR, AND THE GENERAL 
CONTRACTOR.  
25. THE FIRE PROTECTION CONTRACTOR IS RESPONSIBLE FOR COORDINATING CHANGES IN ELECTRICAL 
REQUIREMENTS WITH THE ELECTRICAL CONTRACTOR. 
26. VARIATION FROM SPECIFIED PHYSICAL EQUIPMENT APPEARANCE WILL NEED TO BE APPROVED 
THROUGH THE ARCHITECT. 
27. SYSTEM PIPING WILL BE SUPPORTED AND BRACED WITH HANGERS AND LISTED EARTHQUAKE BRACE 
ASSEMBLIES IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE VA SEISMIC DESIGN REQUIREMENTS AND AND NFPA 13.  
28. AUTOMATIC SPRINKLER SYSTEM SHALL BE SUPERVISED AND INTERFACE WITH FIRE ALARM SYSTEMS. 
29. ONE SET OF STAMPED, APPROVED DRAWINGS SHALL BE ON SITE AT ALL TIMES AND MADE AVAILABLE TO 
THE INSPECTOR AND/OR ARCHITECT/COR UPON DEMAND.  
30. FIRE PROTECTION SYSTEMS SHALL BE INSTALLED BY A CONTRACTOR LICENSED TO PERFORM SUCH 
WORK IN THE PROJECT JURISDICTION.  
31. AVOID DAMAGING EXISTING SURFACES AND EQUIPMENT AND ASSOCIATED MATERIALS FROM THE SITE.  
REPAIR ANY DAMAGE CAUSED DURING WORK AT NO EXTRA COST TO THE COR.  
32. REPAIR FIRE AND SMOKE RATED PARTITIONS SURROUNDING FIRE ALARM WORK AS SPECIFIED. REFER 
TO ARCHITECTURE PLANS FOR LOCATIONS OF SMOKE AND FIRE PARTITIONS.  
33. THREADED BUSHING SHALL NOT BE USED.  
34. REUSE OF ANY SPRINKLER HEAD THAT IS REMOVED FROM SERVICE IS NOT ACCEPTABLE; REFER TO 
NFPA 25, SECTION 5.4.1.1. 
35. NEW ARMOVERS SHALL BE PROVIDED TO EITHER RELOCATED OR NEW SPRINKLERS AS REQUIRED BY 
NFPA 13.  
36. SPRINKLER SYSTEM SHOP DRAWINGS SHALL INCLUDE ALL MATERIALS REQUIRED BY NFPA 13 CHAPTER 
28. 
37. CONTRACTOR SHALL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR ALL CUTTING AND PATCHING OF WALLS AND CEILING AS 
MAY BE REQUIRED FOR THE INSTALLATION OF THE NEW FIRE SUPPRESSION SYSTEM.  
38. INTERRUPTIONS IN OPERATION OF THE FIRE SUPPRESSION SYSTEM MUST BE SCHEDULED WITH THE 
COR IN ADVANCE; WITH PROPER NOTICE PROVIDED TO THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE TEAMS - BOTH 
INSIDE AND OUTSIDE OF THE FACILITY.  
39. WHEN WORK IS BEING PERFORMED IN AREAS THAT MUST CONTINUE OPERATION, CONTRACTOR SHALL 
KEEP THE AREAS CLEAN AND CLEAR OF OBSTRUCTIONS, AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE, PROVIDE WARNING 
SIGNS AS NECESSARY FOR PROTECTION OF OCCUPANTS FROM ASSOCIATED RISKS. REMOVE ALL 
DEBRIS AS WORK PROGRESSES.  
40. UPON COMPLETION OF THE WORK, THE CONTRACTOR SHALL PRESENT THE VA COR WITH A REPORT 
CONFIRMING PROPER TESTING OF ALL NEW AND EXISTING DEVICES IN THE PROJECT ZONE; ALONG WITH 
APPROPRIATE SELECTED TESTING OF THE MAIN FIRE SUPPRESSION SYSTEM TO CONFIRM CONTINUED 
PROPER OPERATION. A CERTIFICATE OF APPROVAL FROM THE APPROPRIATE AGENCY INSPECTION 
AGENT WILL BE REQUIRED PRIOR TO FINAL ACCEPTANCE OF THE PROJECT.  
41. THE PIPING SCHEMATIC INDICATED BY THE DRAWINGS REPRESENTS THE SCOPE AND INTENT OF THE FIRE 
PROTECTION SYSTEM; HOWEVER THE SPRINKLER CONTRACTOR SHALL PROVIDE A COMPLETE SPRINKLER 
SYSTEM PER NFPA 13, NFPA 25, NFPA 101 AND THE VA FIRE PROTECTION DESIGN MANUALREQUIREMENTS. 
42. LIGHT FIXTURES AND HVAC DIFFUSERS TAKE SPACE PREFERENCE, ADD ADDITIONAL SPRINKLER HEADS AS 
REQUIRED TO MEET "COVERAGE REQUIREMENTS". 
43. THE FIRE SUPPRESSION CONTRACTOR SHALL LOCATE SPRINKLER HEADS IN CEILING AS FOLLOWS. ALL 
HEADS SHALL BE LOCATED IN THE CENTER OF THE TILES (2'X2') OR IN THE CENTER OF ONE QUADRANT 
(2'X4') IN GYP/. BOARD CEILING. SPRINKLER HEADS SHALL BE LOCATED IN SYMMETRICAL PATTER RELATIVE 
TO OTHER DEVICES LOCATED IN THE CEILING. 
44. COORDINATE PLACEMENT OF SPRINKLER HEADS WITH ALL MECHANICAL DUCTS, DIFFUSERS AND 
ELECTRICAL LIGHT FIXTURES. 
45. THE FIRE PROTECTION CONTRACTOR SHALL INDICATE ON THEIR SHOP DRAWINGS; CEILING TILE 
LOCATIONS WITH ALL CEILING MOUNTED FIRE PROTECTION DEVICES. 
46. WALL PENETRATIONS THROUGH NON -RATED PARTITIONS SHALL BE PROVIDED WITH A NON -SHRINKING  
GROUT OR CAULKING MATERIAL. 
47. THE FIRE PROTECTION SYSTEM / AREA OF PROTECTION INDICATED ON THE PLANS IS FOR COORDINATION 
AND BIDDING PURPOSES ONLY. THE FIRE PROTECTION CONTRACTOR SHALL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR THE 
COMPLETE DESIGN 
48. ALL PIPING SYSTEMS THAT ARE NOT INTENDED TO BE REUSED SHALL BE REMOVED AND PIPES SHALL BE 
CAPPED AS CLOSE TO MAINS AS POSSIBLE. 
49. IT IS THE INTENTION OF THE SPECIFICATION AND DRAWINGS TO CALL FOR A COMPLETE AND FUNCTIONAL 
SYSTEM, INSTALLED AS PER NFPA 13, NFPA 25, NFPA 101 AND THE VA FIRE PROTECTION DESIGN MANUAL 
WITH ALL FINISHED WORK TESTED AND READY FOR OPERATION. 
50. THE FIRE PROTECTION CONTRACTOR SHALL NOTIFY THE VA COR, VA COR ’S REPRESENTATIVE, FIRE 
ALARM  CONTRACTOR, ARCHITECT AND GENERAL CONTRACTOR ONE WEEK PRIOR TO ANY SHUTDOWN OR 
INTERRUPTION OF SERVICE. 
51. ALL MATERIALS, PIPING, FITTINGS, VALVES, AND APPLIANCES HEREINAFTER SPECIFIED AND THOSE WHICH 
ARE  ESSENTIAL BUT HAVE NOT BEEN SPECIFIED SHALL BE NEW AND OF THE HIGHEST GRADE AND 
QUALITY, FREE FROM DEFECTS AND SUCH AS BREAKS, FLAWS, AND IMPERFECTIONS. 
52. CORE DRILL MASONRY WALLS FOR NEW PIPING. SEAL PENETRATIONS AS NECESSARY TO MAINTAIN 
INTEGRITY OF EXISTING WALLS. 
53. CONTRACTOR SHALL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR ALL CUTTING AND PATCHING OF WALLS AND CEILING AS MAY 
BE REQUIRED FOR THE INSTALLATION OF THE NEW FIRE SUPPRESSION SYSTEM. 
54. ALL APPLIANCES AND APPURTENANCES SHALL BEAR LABEL OF UL/FM APPROVED AND LABELED FOR ITS 
INTENDED USE. 
55. LONG RUNS OF PIPE SHALL BE PROVIDED WITH A SUITABLE MEANS TO PERMIT FREE MOVEMENT 
RESULTING FROM  EXPANSION AND CONTRACTION OF PIPE. REDUCTION IN PIPE SIZES SHALL BE MADE 
WITH ONE -PIECE REDUCTION FITTINGS. 
56. THE FIRE PROTECTION CONTRACTOR IS TO MAINTAIN A SET OF UP TO DATE CONSTRUCTION DOCUMENTS 
AVAILABLE AT THE PROJECT SITE AT ALL TIMES DURING CONSTRUCTION. THE FIRE PROTECTION 
CONTRACTOR IS TO INSTRUCT THE COR ’S REPRESENTATIVE(S) IN THE OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE 
REQUIREMENTS OF THE COMPLETED BUILDING FIRE PROTECTION SYSTEM AT A TIME AGREED ON BY THE 
COR. THE COR ’S REPRESENTATIVE(S) SHALL BE PROVIDED WITH AN UP TO DATE CONSTRUCTION 
DOCUMENTS AND A COPY OF NFPA 25 PRIOR TO INSTRUCTION BY THIS CONTRACTOR. 
57. THIS FIRE SUPPRESSION CONTRACTOR SHALL COORDINATE WITH OTHER WORK, INCLUDING HVAC, 
PLUMBING PIPING, ELECTRICAL AS NECESSARY TO INTERFACE  COMPONENTS OF FIRE SPRINKLER PIPING 
PROPERLY WITH OTHER WORK. SYSTEM PIPING WILL BE SUPPORTED AND  BRACED WITH HANGERS AND 
LISTED EARTHQUAKE BRACE ASSEMBLIES IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE VA SEISMIC DESIGN REQUIREMENTS 
AND NFPA 13. 
58. IT SHALL BE THE RESPONSIBILITY OF THE FIRE SUPPRESSION CONTRACTOR TO REMOVE AND LEGALLY 
DISPOSE OF DEMOLISHED MATERIALS UNLESS NOTED OTHERWISE IN THE DRAWINGS. 
59. ALL WALL AND FLOOR PENETRATIONS SHALL BE CORE -DRILLED AND SLEEVED. 
60. UNLESS INDICATED OTHERWISE IN THE DRAWINGS OR SPECIFICATIONS, FIRE SUPPRESSION CONTRACTOR 
IS RESPONSIBLE FOR SEALING ALL FIRE RATED WALL PARTITIONS WITH UL LISTED MATERIAL AND 
METHODS. 
61. WALL PENETRATIONS THROUGH NON -RATED PARTITIONS SHALL BE PROVIDED WITH A NON -SHRINKING 
GROUT OR CAULKING MATERIAL AND APPROVED ASSEMBLY. 
62. BEFORE SUBMITTING A PROPOSAL FOR THE WORK, EACH BIDDER WILL BE HELD RESPONSIBLE TO HAVE 
EXAMINED THE EXISTING SITE CONDITIONS FOR THE WORK INCLUDED UNDER THIS CONTRACT. NO 
ALLOWANCE WILL BE MADE SUBSEQUENTLY IN THIS CONNECTION ON BEHALF OF THE CONTRACTOR FOR 
ANY ERROR OR NEGLIGENCE ON HIS PART. 
63. THE FIRE SUPPRESSION CONTRACTOR SHALL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR THE COMPLETE DESIGN OF THE FIRE 
PROTECTION SYSTEM AND SHALL PROVIDE SEALED SHOP DRAWINGS.  SPRINKLER SYSTEM PLANS AND 
CALCULATIONS SHALL BE SEALED BY AN PROFESSIONAL ENGINEER REGISTERED IN THE STATE WHERE 
THE WORK IS TO OCCUR, OR SEALED BY A NICET LEVEL III OR LEVEL IV SPRINKLER DESIGNER CERTIFIED IN 
"WATER BASED SYSTEMS LAYOUT". DRAWINGS SHALL BE SEALED IN ACCORDANCE WITH REQUIREMENTS 
OF THE LOCAL AUTHORITY HAVING JURISDICTION. 
64. THE FIRE SUPPRESSION SYSTEM AREA OF PROTECTION INDICATED ON THE PLANS IS FOR COORDINATION 
AND BIDDING PURPOSES ONLY. THE FIRE SUPPRESSION CONTRACTOR SHALL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR THE 
COMPLETE DESIGN. 
65. ALL HANGERS MUST BE FM APPROVED AND UL LISTED TYPE BY NFPA 13. NO SPRINKLER PIPING IS TO BE 
SUPPORTED FROM ANY MECHANICAL OR ELECTRICAL DEVICES. ALL PIPE SHALL BE SUPPORTED FROM THE 
BUILDING STRUCTURE IN A NEAT AND WORKMANLIKE MANNER. VERTICAL RISERS SHOULD BE SUPPORTED 
AT EACH FLOOR LEVEL WITH STEEL PIPE CLAMPS. HANGING PIPES FROM OTHER PIPES WILL BE NOT 
PERMITTED. PIPING SHALL BE  CAREFULLY COORDINATED BEFORE INSTALLATION WITH OTHER SYSTEMS 
AND EQUIPMENT IN CHASES AND OTHER CONGESTED AREAS. MAXIMUM DISTANCES BETWEEN PIPE 
SUPPORTS SHALL MEET THE REQUIREMENT STATED IN NFPA 13, CHAPTER 17. TITLED "MAXIMUM DISTANCE 
BETWEEN HANGERS (FT -IN)." 
66. NO MORE THAN ONE ZONE SHALL BE ALLOWED TO CONTROL ONE SPACE. ONLY ONE ZONE CONTROL 
VALVE SHALL ISOLATE ANY ONE PORTION OF A SYSTEM. 
67. WATER FLOW IN ONE ZONE SHALL NOT CAUSE FIRE ALARMS  IN OTHER ZONES. PROVIDE WATER FLOW  
ALARM SWITCHES WITH RETARD MECHANISM. 
68. THE CONTROL VALVE UTILIZED IN THE STAIRWELLS ON EACH FLOOR SHOULD BE OF THE INDICATING TYPE 
THAT IS READILY VISIBLE TO AN OBSERVER AT FLOOR LEVEL AS TO WHETHER THE VALVE IS OPEN OR 
CLOSED. 
69. VERIFY THAT ALL TAMPER SWITCHES  AND FLOW SWITCHES ARE CONNECTED TO A UL APPROVED FACP 
BY THE FIRE DETECTION CONTRACTOR. 
70. ALL VALVES SHALL BE MADE TAMPER RESISTANT. ELECTRICAL SUPERVISION SHALL BE REQUIRED ON ALL 
SPRINKLER CONTROL VALVES. INDICATOR VALVES SHALL BE MADE EASILY READABLE AND READILY 
ACCESSIBLE. 
71. EACH SPRINKLER ZONES IS TO BE PROVIDED WITH A DEDICATED CONTROL VALVE, TAMPER SWITCH AND 
AN INSPECTOR'S TEST. 
72. TAMPER SWITCHES ON OS&Y TYPE VALVES MUST NOT DISTORT OR CHANGE SWITCH SETTINGS AS THEIR 
BOLTS ARE SECURELY FASTENED. NO "J -BOLT" MOUNTS WILL BE PERMITTED. 
73. MAINTAINABILITY 
A. EXTERNAL AND INTERNAL PARTS SHALL BE ARRANGED SO THAT WHEN INSTALLED, ALL PARTS 
REQUIRING MANIPULATION, OBSERVATION, AND/OR MAINTENANCE ARE READILY ACCESSIBLE AND 
SAFE FOR OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE PERSONNEL. WHEREVER PRACTICAL, VALVES AND 
INSTRUMENTS SHALL BE LOCATED SUCH THAT THEY CAN BE OPERATED AND EASILY ACCESSED FROM 
GRADE LEVEL. 
B. MAINTAINABILITY SHALL BE INCORPORATED INTO THE DESIGN OF ALL CONTRACTOR SUPPLIED 
EQUIPMENT. THE PRIMARY MAINTAINABILITY OBJECT SHALL BE TO MINIMIZE THE COMPLEXITY AND 
TIME REQUIRED FOR MAINTENANCE. THE FOLLOWING GENERAL CRITERIA SHALL BE FOLLOWED TO 
ACHIEVE THIS OBJECTIVE: 
1. CONTRACTOR SUPPLIED EQUIPMENT SHALL BE LOW MAINTENANCE DESIGN AND SHALL BE EASILY 
MAINTAINABLE.  
2. CONTRACTOR SUPPLIED EQUIPMENT SHALL BE DESIGNED TO BE MAINTAINED IN PLACE, IF 
POSSIBLE, WITH MINIMUM DISASSEMBLY OF SURROUNDING EQUIPMENT AND MINIMUM USAGE OF 
TEMPORARY SCAFFOLDING AND HANDLING EQUIPMENT.  
74. DEVICES SHOWN ON THIS PLAN ARE NEW, UNLESS OTHERWISE NOTED.  
75. DRAWING ARE DIAGRAMMATIC AND ARE NOT INTENDED TO SHOW EACH AND EVERY SPRINKLER HEAD, 
BRANCH PIPING, DEVICES, FITTINGS, VALVES OR COMPLETE DETAIL OF ALL THE WORK TO BE PERFORMED, 
BUT ARE FOR THE PURPOSES OF ILLUSTRATING THE TYPE OF SYSTEM AND CONDITIONS NECESSARY FOR 
AN EXPERIENCED TRADESMAN TO LAYOUT HIS WORK. THE CONTRACTOR SHALL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR 
MAKING SUCH SITE OBSERVATIONS AND MEASUREMENTS AS NECESSARY TO PROPERLY COMPLETE THE 
WORK. 
76. WHERE WORK IS BEING PERFORMED IN AREAS THAT MUST CONTINUE NORMAL OPERATION, CONTRACTOR 
SHALL KEEP THE AREAS CLEAN AND CLEAR OF OBSTRUCTIONS, AND AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE, PROVIDE 
WARNING SIGNS AS NECESSARY FOR PROTECTION OF OCCUPANTS FROM ASSOCIATED RISKS. REMOVE 
ALL DEBRIS AS WORK PROGRESSES. 
77. THE PIPING SCHEMATIC INDICATED BY THE DRAWINGS REPRESENTS THE SCOPE AND INTENT OF THE FIRE 
PROTECTION SYSTEM; HOWEVER THE SPRINKLER CONTRACTOR SHALL PROVIDE A COMPLETE SPRINKLER 
SYSTEM PER NFPA 13, NFPA 25, NFPA 101, VA FIRE PROTECTION DESIGN MANUAL AND VA FIRE OFFICIAL 
REQUIREMENTS. 
78. REFER TO ARCHITECTURAL REFLECTED CEILING PLAN FOR COORDINATION OF SPRINKLER LOCATIONS 
WITH CEILING HEIGHTS AND TYPES. LOCATE SPRINKLER HEADS THROUGHOUT ALL AREAS AS REQUIRED 
BY NFPA 13, AND VA FIR PROTECTION DESIGN MANUAL. COORDINATE SPRINKLER HEAD LOCATIONS WITH 
ALL OTHER TRADES BUT NOT LIMITED TO THE FOLLOWING: LIGHTS, STRUCTURAL SUPPORTS, BOOM, 
SPECIAL SYSTEMS, SMOKE DETECTORS, FIRE ALARM INDICATION DEVICES, HVAC DIFFUSERS, ETC. OBTAIN 
ARCHITECT'S, ENGINEER AND/OR APPROVAL OF ALL SPRINKLER HEAD LOCATIONS. 
79. ALL SPRINKLER HEAD PIPE ROUTING AND ELEVATIONS SHALL BE COORDINATED WITH ALL OTHER TRADES 
INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO THE FOLLOWING: CEILINGS, STRUCTURAL STEEL AND SUPPORTS, HVAC 
DUCTWORK, CABLE TRAYS, CONDUIT, SPECIAL SYSTEMS, CONTROLS, ETC. 
80. THE AUTOMATIC SPRINKLER CONTRACTOR IS TO PROVIDE ALL NECESSARY OFFSETS, RISES OR DROPS IN 
THE PIPING AND AUXILIARY DRAINS AS REQUIRED TO INSTALL COMPLETELY COORDINATED SPRINKLER 
SYSTEM.  HYDRAULIC CALCULATIONS SHALL BE ORIGINATED AT THE FIRE PUMP AS A MINIMUM FOR 
FACILITIES THAT POSSES A FIRE PUMP OR AT LOCATION OF FIRE HYDRANT FLOW TEST. 
81. SPRINKLER HEADS SHALL BE LOCATED A MINIMUM OF TWO (2) FOOT DISTANCE FROM A SIDE WALL -
MOUNTED OR CEILING MOUNTED DIFFUSER USING AN ORDINARY TEMPERATURE SPRINKLER HEAD.  
SPRINKLER HEADS SHALL BE LOCATED A MINIMUM OF THREE (3) FOOT DISTANCE FROM THE FRONT OF A 
WALL -MOUNTED HOT AIR DIFFUSER. 
82. SPRINKLER HEADS SHALL BE LOCATED A MINIMUM OF 18 INCHES FROM ANY LIGHT FIXTURE USING AN 
ORDINARY TEMPERATURE SPRINKLER HEAD. IT IS PREFERRED THAT THE CONTRACTOR MAINTAINS A TWO 
(2) FOOT SPACING BETWEEN THE LIGHT FIXTURE AND SPRINKLER HEAD. 
83. SPRINKLER PLANS AS SHOWN ARE FOR BIDDING PURPOSES ONLY. SPRINKLER CONTRACTOR IS TO OBTAIN 
CURRENT HYDRANT TEST OR FIRE PUMP TEST DATA AND PROVIDE HYDRAULIC CALCULATIONS FOR 
SYSTEM PIPE SIZING IN ACCORDANCE WITH NFPA 13 AND THE VA FIRE PROTECTION DESIGN MANUAL.  
CONTRACTOR IS TO SUBMIT SHOP DRAWINGS INDICATING HYDRAULIC CALCULATIONS, PIPING LAYOUT & 
SIZING. ALL WORK IS TO BE DONE IN ACCORDANCE WITH NFPA 13, NFPA 25, NFPA 101, NFPA 291 AND THE 
VA FIRE PROTECTION DESIGN MANUAL. 
84. SPRINKLER CONTRACTOR SHALL MAINTAIN SUPERVISION OF EXISTING SPRINKLER SYSTEM AT ALL TIMES 
AND SHALL COORDINATE TRANSFER OF SYSTEM WITH VA COR AND ENGINEER OF RECORD. 
85. CONFLICTS BETWEEN NATIONALLY RECOGNIZED CODES AND THE VA DESIGN REQUIREMENTS SHOULD A  
CONFLICT EXIST BETWEEN THE VA REQUIREMENTS AND THE VA ADOPTED CODES, THE CONFLICT SHALL 
BE BROUGHT TO THE ATTENTION OF THE ENGINEER AND VA. THE RESOLUTION OF THE CONFLICT SHALL 
BE MADE BY THE CONSISTENT SYSTEM WIDE DESIGN. 
86. HYDRAULIC CALCULATIONS SHALL BE ORIGINATED AT THE LOCATION OF THE EXISTING HOSPITAL'S FIRE 
PUMP TO BE PERFORMED BY THE CONTRACTOR AS THEIR DESIGN INPUTS. A NEW FIRE PUMP TEST AT 0%, 
100% AND 150% SHALL BE PERFORMED BY THIS CONTRACTOR AND SHALL BE SUBMITTED AND USED AS A 
DESIGN INPUT TO THE HYDRAULIC CALCULATIONS. 
87. ALL MAINS AND CONTROL VALVES, INCLUDING THE WATER SUPPLY CONTROL VALVES, SHALL HAVE A SIGN 
INDICATING THE PORTION OF THE SYSTEM THAT IS CONTROLLED BY THE VALVE AND THE VALVE SHALL 
HAVE A IDENTIFICATION / VALVE TAG NUMBER. ALL ISOLATION VALVES SHALL BE ELECTRONICALLY 
SUPERVISED BY TAMPER/WATER FLOW SWITCHES AND THEY SHALL INTERFACE WITH THE FIRE 
ALARM/FIRE DETECTION SYSTEM. 
88. THE FIRE SUPPRESSION CONTRACTOR SHALL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR THE COMPLETE DESIGN OF THE FIRE 
PROTECTION SYSTEM AND SHALL PROVIDE SEALED SHOP DRAWINGS. SPRINKLER PLANS AND 
CALCULATIONS SHALL BE SEALED BY A PROFESSIONAL ENGINEER REGISTERED IN THE STATE OF GEORGIA 
OR A NICET LEVEL III OR LEVEL IV SPRINKLER DESIGNER. 
89. THE CONTROL VALVE UTILIZED IN THE STAIRWELLS ON EACH FLOOR SHOULD BE OF THE INDICATING TYPE 
THAT IS READILY VISIBLE TO AN OBSERVER AT THE FLOOR LEVEL AS TO WHETHER THE VALVE IS OPEN OR 
CLOSED. 
90. ALL VALVES SHALL BE MADE TAMPER RESISTANT. ELECTRICAL SUPERVISION SHALL BE REQUIRED ON ALL 
SPRINKLER CONTROL VALVES. INDICATOR VALVE SHALL BE MADE READABLE AND READILY ACCESSIBLE. 
91. EACH SPRINKLER ZONE IS TO BE PROVIDED WITH A DEDICATED CONTROL VALVE, TAMPER SWITCH AND AN 
INSPECTOR TEST. 
92. ALL SPRINKLER HEADS SHALL BE QUICK RESPONSE PENDENT TYPE HEADS AND IF IN THE EXISTING 
BUILDING THERE IS A DIFFERENT TYPE THEN ALL SPRINKLER HEADS SHALL BE OF QUICK RESPONSE TYPE. 
CONTRACTOR SHALL VERIFY EXISTING SPRINKLER HEAD TYPE BEFORE WORK BEGINS. 
93. WET PIPE SYSTEMS FOR THE SCOPE OF WORK AREA SHALL MEET THE FOLLOWING REQUIREMENT: 
A. WET PIPE SYSTEM SPRINKLER PIPES SHALL BE PERMITTED TO BE INSTALLED LEVEL MEETING THE 
REQUIREMENTS OF NFPA 13, 2022 EDITION, SECTION 16.10.2. 
B. ANY TRAPPED PIPING WHERE THE BRANCH LINES OR MAINS ARE LOCATED AT A LEVEL THAT CAN NOT 
BE DRAINED AT THE WET PIPE ASSEMBLY DRAIN VALVE(S) SHALL MEET THE REQUIREMENTS OF NFPA 
13, 2022 EDITION, SECTION 16.10.5 AND VA FIRE PROTECTION DESIGN MANUAL, SECTION 6.1.P. 
a. THE AUXILIARY DRAIN PIPING SHALL BE A MINIMUM SIZE OF 2 -INCH TO ACCOMMODATE DISCHARGE 
FROM FULL FLOW TESTS AT MAXIMUM SYSTEM PRESSURE AT THE EXTERIOR. DESIGN EXTERIOR 
DRAINS TO PREVENT FLOODING OR DAMAGE TO LANDSCAPING AND TO PREVENT WETTING OF 
WALKWAYS. 
94. THIS CONTRACTOR IS RESPONSIBLE FOR SUBMISSION OF CONTRACTOR'S MATERIAL AND TEST 
CERTIFICATE FOR ABOVEGROUND PIPING MEETING NFPA 13, FIGURE 29.1 TO THE VA COR AND THE 
ENGINEER OF RECORD FOR REVIEW AND COMMENT BY THE VA AND ENGINEER OF RECORD. THE 
CONTRACTOR'S MATERIAL AND TEST CERTIFICATE FOR ABOVEGROUND PIPING MUST BE DATED, PRINTED 
NAME OF INDIVIDUALS WHO SIGNED THE SYSTEM RECORD OF COMPLETION AND SIGNATURES. ALL TEST 
MUST BE COORDINATED WITH THE VA COR, VA FIRE SAFETY OFFICIAL AND THE ENGINEER OF RECORD. 
SIGNATURES BY NON VA FIRE OFFICIALS WILL NOT BE ACCEPTED. 
95. ALL PIPING, SPRINKLER HEADS, AND SPRINKLER WORK SHALL BE COORDINATED TO THE ARCHITECTURAL, 
STRUCTURAL, MECHANICAL, PLUMBING AND ELECTRICAL WORK. PIPING SHALL BE CONCEALED, EXCEPT 
WHERE SO INDICATED OR WHERE ABSOLUTELY NECESSARY TO BE EXPOSED. EXPOSED PIPING SHALL BE 
PLACED AS APPROVED BY THE VA FIRE OFFICIAL AND THE ENGINEER OF RECORD, PRIOR TO 
INSTALLATION. SPRINKLER HEADS SHALL BE FULLY COORDINATED WITH ARCHITECTURAL REFLECTED 
CEILING PLAN. 
96. THE LOCATION OF THE FIRE SPRINKLER HEADS SHALL BE COORDINATED WITH CEILING LAYOUT AND ALL 
OTHER TRADES FOR COMPLETE FIRE PROTECTION COVERAGE OF ALL AREAS. PROVIDED DETAILED PLANS 
FOR APPROVAL BY THE VA FIRE OFFICIAL, AND THE ENGINEER OF RECORD, PRIOR TO INSTALLATION .

DEMOLITION GENERAL NOTES 
A. EXISTING FIRE SPRINKLERS SHALL REMAIN IN SERVICE AS LONG AS POSSIBLE, 
WHILE DEMOLITION WORK IS IN PROGRESS. ANY DISRUPTIONS IN THE FIRE 
SPRINKLER SYSTEM SERVICE SHALL BE PROVIDED WITH AN APPROVED FIRE 
WATCH OR STANDBY PERSONNEL PROVIDED BY THE CONTRACTOR. 
B. REMOVE ALL EXISTING FIRE SPRINKLERS IN THE AREAS INDICATED ON THIS 
SHEET AND CUT AND CAP THE PIPING BACK TO THE CONNECTION OF THE ARM 
OVER. FOR FLEXIBLE HOSE CONNECTIONS, REUSE OF THE FLEXIBLE HOSE IS 
AT THE CONTRACTORS RISK; CAP THE OPEN PIPE AT THE FLEXIBLE HOSE 
CONNECTION TO THE SPRINKLER PIPING. 
C. EXISTING FIRE SPRINKLER SYSTEM SHALL REMAIN IN SERVICES AS LONG AS 
POSSIBLE WHILE THE DEMOLITION WORK IS IN PROGRESS. 
D. FIRE SUPPRESSION SPRINKLERS SHALL BE REPLACED, RELOCATED AND/OR 
ADDED IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE REQUIREMENTS FOR NFPA 13. 
E. EXISTING FIRE SUPPRESSION SUPPLY SHALL BE DRAINED PRIOR TO ANY 
DEMOLITION WORK ON THE WET PIPE SPRINKLER SUPPLY FROM THE 
INDIVIDUAL FLOOR CONTROL VALVE TO THE MOST REMOTE SPRINKLER HEAD. 
F. EXISTING FLOOR CONTROL VALVE SHALL BE SECURED/CLOSED FOR 
DEMOLITION AND NEW WORK. 
G. ALL WORK SHALL BE PERFORMED AS TO NOT INTERRUPT SERVICE TO THE 
ENTIRE AFFECTED FLOOR. THE CONTRACTOR SHALL PROPERLY NOTIFY THE 
BUILDING OWNER AS APPLICABLE A MINIMUM OF 1 WEEK IN ADVANCE BEFORE 
PROCEEDING WITH THIS WORK. 
H. REMOVE ALL UNUSED AND DEMOLISHED EQUIPMENT AND ASSOCIATED 
MATERIAL FORM THE SITE. ABANDONING UNUSED PORTIONS WILL NOT BE 
ACCEPTABLE. OWNER SHALL HAVE THE RIGHT OF REFUGE OWNERSHIP OF ALL 
DEMOLISHED AND UNUSED PORTION OF EQUIPMENT AND MATERIALS. 
I. AVOID DAMAGING EXISTING SURFACES AND EQUIPMENT AND ASSOCIATED 
MATERIALS FROM THE SITE. REPAIR ANY DAMAGE CAUSED DURING WORK AT 
NO EXTRA COST TO THE OWNER. 
J. ALL SYSTEMS ARE TO BE LEFT IN SERVICE PRIOR TO THE END OF EACH 
WORKDAY. 
K. REMOVE ANY CEILING TILES, GRID, AND LIGHT FIXTURES REQUIRED TO 
ACCOMPLISH THE WORK. REPLACE SAME AFTER THE INSTALLATION IS 
COMPLETE. IT IS THE CONTRACTOR'S RESPONSIBILITY TO REPLACE ANY ITEMS 
DAMAGED DURING CONSTRUCTION. 
L. MODIFY EXISTING SPRINKLER SYSTEM, RELOCATE AND/OR PROVIDE 
ADDITIONAL SPRINKLERS, PIPING, HANGERS, ETC., COORDINATE WITH WALLS, 
CEILINGS, LIGHTS, DIFFUSERS, STRUCTURE, OBSTRUCTIONS, ETC., IN AREAS 
AFFECTED BY THE SCOPE OF WORK. 
M. REMOVE ALL ABANDONED PIPING, WET SPRINKLERS, FITTINGS, HANGERS, 
ETC., FROM THE PROJECT LOCATION. DISPOSE OF ALL MATERIAL LEGALLY TO 
AN APPROVED DISPOSAL SITE. 
N. THE CONTRACTOR SHALL FIELD VERIFY ALL EXISTING ELECTRICAL LINES, 
PLUMBING LINES, DUCTWORK OR MECHANICAL PIPING LOCATED IN THE 
CEILING SPACE, WALLS OR FLOOR PRIOR TO SAW CUTTING OR ANY CORE 
DRILLING. IT IS THE CONTRACTOR'S RESPONSIBILITY TO REPAIR SUCH ITEMS 
DAMAGED. 
O. FIRE SPRINKLER SYSTEM(S) NOT ASSOCIATED WITH THE DEMOLITION SHALL BE 
LEFT IN SERVICE AS APPLICABLE. 
P. COORDINATE SPRINKLER SYSTEM MODIFICATIONS TO MINIMIZE SYSTEM 
IMPAIRMENT. PROVIDE FIRE WATCH AND INTERIM FIRE PROTECTION 
MEASURES WHERE REQUIRED BY THE AUTHORITY HAVING JURISDICTION OR 
THE OWNER. 
Q. ALL SHUTDOWNS SHALL BE COORDINATED AND APPROVED THROUGH THE VA 
COR AND VA FIRE OFFICIAL'S REPRESENTATIVE AND SHALL REQUIRE A 
MINIMUM OF 15 DAYS ADVANCE NOTICE, THIS TIME LENGTH MAY BE LONGER 
OR SHORTER FOR SOME SHUTDOWNS AND SHALL BE AT THE VA COR'S 
DISCRETION. DRAINING AND REFILLING OF EXISTING SYSTEM IS 
RESPONSIBILITY OF THE FIRE SUPPRESSION CONTRACTOR'S 
REPRESENTATIVE. 
R. ALL DISRUPTIONS IN THE FIRE SUPPRESSION SYSTEM SHALL BE 
COMPENSATED WITH AN APPROVED FIRE WATCH AND STANDBY PERSONAL. 
REFER TO THIS DRAWING FOR THE PROCEDURES AND REQUIREMENTS 
DURING A FIRE SUPPRESSION SYSTEM IMPAIRMENT IN ADDITION TO DIVISION 
01, SPECIFICATION 01 35 26, SAFETY REQUIREMENTS THAT NEED TO BE MET BY 
THIS FIRE SUPPRESSION CONTRACTOR. 
PROCEDURES FOR DRAINING WET PIPE SYSTEM 
1. TO DRAIN A WET PIPE SYSTEM THE PROCEDURE TO BE PERFORMED AND SUBMITTED TO THE ARCHITECT, 
ENGINEER, VA COR AND VA FIRE SAFETY OFFICIAL SHOULD INCLUDE BUT NOT LIMITED TO THE FOLLOWING. 
1.1. CLOSE ALL SPRINKLER CONTROL VALVES. 
1.2. TAG ALL CLOSED VALVES. 
1.3. OPEN MAIN DRAIN VALVES AND AUXILIARY DRAINS ALLOWING THE SYSTEM FOR 100% COMPLETE 
DRAINAGE. 
1.4. WHEN THE WATER HAS BEEN COMPLETELY DRAINED, CLOSE THE MAIN DRAIN AND AUXILIARY 
DRAIN VALVES. WHEN THE WATER HAS STOPPED FLOWING, CHECK ALL CONTROL VALVES TO BE SURE 
THEY ARE TIGHTLY SHUT; ANY MALFUNCTION CONTROL VALVES SHOULD BE REPAIRED AND/OR 
REPLACED IMMEDIATELY AS DEEMED APPLICABLE. 
1.5. CHECK FOR WATER TRAPPED AT ALL LOW POINTS IN PIPING THAT LACK AUXILIARY DRAINS; REMOVE 
DRAIN AND REPLACE SUCH PIPING. 
1.6. ONCE ABOVE ITEM ARE CONFIRMED WITH 100% CERTAINTY THE CONTRACTOR SHALL PERFORM ALL 
NEW INSTALLATIONS. 
1. MINIMUM REQUIREMENTS 
A. THE FIRE SUPPRESSION CONTRACTOR SHALL ENACT MEASURES THAT SHALL BE TAKEN 
DURING THE IMPAIRMENT TO ENSURE THAT INCREASED RISKS ARE MINIMIZED AND THE 
DURATION OF THE IMPAIRMENT IS LIMITED. 
B. THE FIRE SUPPRESSION CONTRACTOR SHALL NOTIFY IN WRITING TO THE ARCHITECT, 
ENGINEER, OWNER AND ANY JURISDICTION HAVING AUTHORITY OF THE PLANNED IMPAIRMENT, 
PROCEDURES DURING THE IMPAIRMENT, TESTING RE -COMMISSIONING OF THE FIRE 
PROTECTION/FIRE ALARM SYSTEMS FOR PROTECTION OF THE AFFECTED LOCATIONS WITHIN 
THE SCOPE OF WORK SUITE. 
C. THE FIRE SUPPRESSION CONTRACTOR THROUGH THE OWNER SHALL PREPARE AND SUBMIT TO 
THE OWNER FOR OWNER'S DISTRIBUTION TO THE EMPLOYEES IN THE AREA OF THE 
IMPAIRMENT SHALL BE PROVIDED WITH INFORMATION ON ALTERNATE FIRE PROTECTION THAT 
WILL BE AVAILABLE. 
D. THE SUSPENSION OF ALL NON -ESSENTIAL HOT WORK PERMITS UNTIL THE CONCLUSION AND 
REACTIVATION OF THE FIRE SUPPRESSION SYSTEM AND INTERFACING FIRE DETECTION 
SYSTEM. 
2. FIRE PROTECTION IMPAIRMENT PLAN 
A. A FIRE PROTECTION IMPAIRMENT PLAN SHOULD BE DEVELOPED AND IMPLEMENTED BEFORE 
AUTHORIZATION IS GIVEN, THE IMPAIRMENT COORDINATOR SHOULD VERIFY THAT THE 
FOLLOWING PROCEDURES HAVE BEEN IMPLEMENTED: 
• THE EXTENT AND EXPECTED DURATION OF THE IMPAIRMENT THAT HAS BEEN DETERMINED. 
• THE AREA OF THE BUILDING THAT WILL BE AFFECTED HAS BEEN INSPECTED AND THE 
INCREASED RISKS DETERMINED. 
• RECOMMENDATIONS HAVE BEEN SUBMITTED TO THE ARCHITECT, ENGINEER AND OWNER 
OR OWNER'S REPRESENTATIVE TO MITIGATE ANY INCREASED RISKS. 
• WHERE A REQUIRED FIRE PROTECTION SYSTEM IS OUT OF SERVICE FOR MORE THAN TEN 
HOURS IN A 24 HOUR PERIOD THE CONTRACTOR & OWNER SHALL ARRANGE FOR THE 
FOLLOWING: 
• AN APPROVED CONTRACTOR'S FIRE WATCH. 
• ESTABLISHMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF AN APPROVED PROGRAM TO ELIMINATE 
POTENTIAL IGNITION SOURCES AND LIMIT OF THE AMOUNT OF COMBUSTIBLES IN THE 
AREA OF CONSTRUCTION. 
• ASSIGN PERSONNEL TO TRANSMIT FIRE ALARMS TO THE VA HOSPITAL COORDINATOR 
WHERE THE MAIN FIRE ALARM PANEL IS BEING MONITORED FOR 24/7 COVERAGE. 
3. TAG IMPAIRMENT SYSTEM 
A. A TAG SHALL BE USED TO INDICATE THAT A SYSTEM OR PART THERE OF, HAS BEEN REMOVED 
FROM SERVICE. THE FIRE SUPPRESSION CONTRACTOR SHALL PLACE TAGS ON ALL AFFECTED 
COMPONENTS, E.G., TAMPER SWITCHES, VALVES, FIRE ALARM ANNUNICATOR DEVICES, ETC., 
PRIOR TO THE COMMENCEMENT OF ANY WORK. 
B. THE TAG SHALL BE POSTED AT EACH FIRE PROTECTION CONNECTION AND SYSTEM CONTROL 
VALVE AND OTHER LOCATION REQUIRED BY THE OWNER'S REPRESENTATIVE OR ANY AND ALL 
AUTHORITIES HAVING JURISDICTION, INDICATING WHICH SYSTEM, OR PART THERE OF, HAS 
BEEN REMOVED FROM SERVICE. 
• THE SUPERVISORS IN THE AREA TO THE AFFECTED AREA HAS BEEN NOTIFIED. 
• THE FIRE DEPARTMENT HAS BEEN NOTIFIED. 
• A TAG IMPAIRMENT SYSTEM HAVE BEEN IMPLEMENTED. 
• ALL NECESSARY TOOLS, EQUIPMENT, MATERIAL AND APPURTENANCES ARE LOCATED AND 
ASSEMBLED ON THE IMPAIRMENT SITE. 
4. RESTORING SYSTEMS TO SERVICE 
A. WHEN ALL IMPAIRED EQUIPMENT IS RESTORED TO NORMAL WORKING ORDER, THE ARCHITECT/ 
ENGINEER SHALL VERIFY THAT THE CONTRACTOR HAS IMPLEMENTED THE FOLLOWING 
PROCEDURES: 
• ALL NECESSARY INSPECTION HAVE BEEN CONDUCTED FOLLOWING NFPA 13, 25 AND 72 
REQUIREMENTS IN ORDER TO VERIFY THAT THE AFFECTED SYSTEM ARE OPERATION. 
CONTRACTOR SHALL SUBMIT ALL REQUIRED RECORDS AND RECORDS SHALL INDICATE THE 
PROCEDURE PERFORMED, THE ORGANIZATION THAT PERFORMED THE WORK, RESULTS 
AND THE DATE. 
• OPEN ALL VALVES THAT WERE SECURED DURING THE IMPAIRMENT. 
• REMOVE IMPAIRMENT TAG ONCE VALVES ARE OPEN. 
• CONDUCT A DRAIN TEST IN THE WIDE OPEN POSITION. 
• ENSURE THE FIRE PROTECTION SYSTEM IS PLACED BACK TO "AUTOMATIC" SERVICE. 
• RESET FIRE ALARM SYSTEM AND NOTIFY OWNER'S REPRESENTATIVE AND FIRE ALARM 
COMPANY THAT MONITORS THE OWNER'S MAIN FIRE ALARM PANEL ON 24/7 COVERAGE. 
• ARCHITECT, ENGINEER AND OWNERS REPRESENTATIVE HAVE BEEN ADVISED THAT THE 
FIRE PROTECTION AND FIRE DETECTION SYSTEM THAT WAS IMPAIRED HAS BEEN 
RESTORED. 
• THE OWNER'S REPRESENTATIVE OR DESIGNATED REPRESENTATIVE, FIRE ALARM COMPANY 
WHO MONITORS THE MAIN FIRE ALARM PANEL FOR 24/7 COVERAGE AND ALL OTHER 
JURISDICTIONS HAVE BEEN ADVISED THAT BOTH FIRE PROTECTION SYSTEMS IS RESTORED. 
• THE IMPAIRMENT TAG HAS BEEN REMOVED. 
• COORDINATE ALL PROCEDURES WITH VA CONTRACTING OFFICER REPRESENTATIVE AND 
DESIGNATED FIRE SAFETY OFFICIAL. 
PROCEDURES FOR IMPAIRMENT TO THE FIRE PROTECTION 
SYSTEM 
FIRE WATCH PROCEDURES AND REQUIREMENTS 
A. THE FIRE SUPPRESSION CONTRACTOR'S FIRE WATCH PERSONNEL SHALL BE TRAINED TO 
UNDERSTAND THE INHERENT HAZARDS OF THE WORK SITE AND OF THE HOT WORK TO OCCUR. 
B. THE FIRE SUPPRESSION CONTRACTOR'S FIRE WATCH SHALL ENSURE THAT SAFE CONDITIONS 
ARE MAINTAINED DURING OUTAGE OF THE FIRE ALARM/FIRE SUPPRESSION SYSTEM AND/OR 
DURING THE OCCURRENCE OF HOT WORK OPERATION. 
C. THE FIRE SUPPRESSION CONTRACTOR'S FIRE WATCH SHALL HAVE THE AUTHORITY TO STOP HOT 
WORK OPERATIONS IF UNSAFE OPERATIVE DEVELOPS. 
D. THE FIRE SUPPRESSION CONTRACTOR'S FIRE WATCH SHALL HAVE FIRE EXTINGUISHING 
EQUIPMENT READILY AVAILABLE AND TRAINED IN ITS USE, E.G., FIRE EXTINGUISHERS. 
E. THE FIRE SUPPRESSION CONTRACTOR'S FIRE WATCH SHALL BE FAMILIAR WITH OWNER'S 
FACILITIES AND PROCEDURES FOR SOUNDING AN ALARM IN THE EVENT OF A FIRE. 
F. THE FIRE SUPPRESSION CONTRACTOR'S FIRE WATCH SHALL WATCH FOR FIRES IN ALL EXPOSED 
AREAS AND TRY TO EXTINGUISH A FIRE ONLY WHEN THE FIRES ARE OBVIOUSLY WITHIN THE 
CAPACITY OF THE AVAILABLE EXTINGUISHING EQUIPMENT. IF THE FIRE WATCH DETERMINES THAT 
THE FIRE IS NOT WITHIN THE CAPACITY OF THE EQUIPMENT THE FIRE WATCH SHALL SOUND AN 
ALARM IMMEDIATELY (E.G.,INITIATE A MANUALLY ACTUATED ALARM INDICATING DEVICE THAT IS 
OUTSIDE OF THE CONSTRUCTION AREA DURING THE DISRUPTION OF THE FIRE ALARM/DETECTION 
WITHIN THE CONSTRUCTION WORK SCOPE OR WITHIN THE CONSTRUCTION WORK SCOPE IF THE 
FIRE ALARM/DETECTION SYSTEM HAS BEEN ACTIVATED). 
G. BEFORE STARTING ANY HOT WORK, CONTRACTORS AND THEIR OWNERS SHALL DISCUSS THE 
PLANNED PROJECT COMPLETELY INCLUDING THE TYPE OF HOT WORK TO BE CONDUCTED AND THE 
HAZARDS IN THE AREA WITH THE ASSOCIATED PLAN OF ACTION, IN ORDER, TO PROVIDE EQUIVALENT 
SAFETY MEASURES TAKEN DURING THE FIRE DETECTION OR FIRE SUPPRESSION IMPAIRMENT. 
A. THE FIRE SUPPRESSION CONTRACTOR SHALL BE REQUIRED TO HAVE AN OVERALL FIRE SAFETY 
PROGRAM THAT SHALL INCLUDE: 
B. FIRE PROTECTION SERVICES AS FOLLOWS: 
1. DURING RENOVATION TO THE EXISTING BUILDING'S SCOPE OF WORK AREAS PRESERVATION 
OF EXISTING SYSTEMS DURING DEMOLITION SHALL BE KEPT FULLY OPERATIONAL AS LONG 
AS FEASIBLY POSSIBLE AND KEEP DISRUPTIONS TO FIRE ALARM AND FIRE SPRINKLER 
SYSTEM SHALL BE KEPT TO A MINIMUM. 
2. COORDINATE REQUIREMENTS AND RESPONSIBILITIES WITH THE OWNER'S REPRESENTATIVE 
AND DESIGNATED VA FIRE SAFETY REPRESENTATIVE ON RESPONSIBILITIES OF FIRE 
FIGHTING OR CONTACTING OF LOCAL FIRE DEPARTMENT. CLEARLY DELINEATE THE DIVISION 
OF RESPONSIBILITIES BETWEEN THE VA AND CONTRACTOR DURING A FIRE INCIDENT. 
3. DEVELOPMENT AND DOCUMENTATION OF A PRE -FIRE PLAN WITH THE VA FIRE SAFETY 
OFFICIAL AND THE LOCAL FIRE DEPARTMENT THAT WOULD PROVIDE FIRE FIGHTING 
SERVICES DURING A FIRE OCCURRENCE. 
4. RAPID COMMUNICATION WITH THE VA FIRE SAFETY OFFICIAL. 
5. CONSIDERATION OF SPECIAL HAZARDS RESULTING FROM PREVIOUS SPACE USE. 
C. PROTECTION OF EXISTING STRUCTURES AND EQUIPMENT FROM EXPOSURE FIRES RESULTING 
FROM CONSTRUCTION, ALTERATION AND DEMOLITION OPERATIONS. 
1. VA RESPONSIBILITIES FOR FIRE PROTECTION: 
• THE VA SHALL DESIGNATE A PERSON WHO SHALL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR THE FIRE 
PREVENTION PROGRAM AND WHO SHALL ENSURE THAT IT IS CARRIED OUT TO 
COMPLETION. 
• THE VA FIRE PREVENTION MANAGER SHALL HAVE THE AUTHORITY TO ENFORCE THE 
PROVISION OS THIS AND OTHER APPLICABLE FIRE PROTECTION STANDARDS. 
• THE VA FIRE PREVENTION PROGRAM MANAGER SHALL HAVE THE KNOWLEDGE OF THE 
APPLICABLE FIRE PROTECTION STANDARDS, AVAILABLE FIRE PROTECTION SYSTEMS 
AND FIRE INSPECTION PROCEDURES. 
• THE VA FIRE PROTECTION INSPECTION RECORDS SHALL BE AVAILABLE FOR REVIEW BY 
ANY AUTHORITY HAVING JURISDICTION. 
D. FIRE ALARM REQUIREMENTS: 
1. THE FIRE ALARM CONTRACTOR SHALL COORDINATE WITH THE OWNER'S REPRESENTATIVE 
AND THE DESIGNATED VA FIRE OFFICIAL AS TO THE CLOSEST READILY ACCESSIBLE PUBLIC 
FIRE ALARM BOX NEAR THE CONSTRUCTION PREMISE  TO REPORT A FIRE INCIDENT OR 
OCCURRENCE. 
• INSTRUCTIONS SHALL BE CREATED AND ISSUED FOR ALL CONTRACTOR AND SUB -TIER 
CONTRACTORS  FOR PROCEDURES FOR IMMEDIATE NOTIFICATION TO THE VA FIRE 
SAFETY REPRESENTATIVE AND/OR LOCAL FIRE DEPARTMENT IN THE CASE OF A FIRE. 
WHERE TELEPHONE SERVICE IS EMPLOYED, E.G., CELLULAR OF LAND LINE SERVICE  TO 
THE RESPONDING FIRE DEPARTMENT OR EQUIVALENT FACILITIES. 
2. THE FIRE ALARM CONTRACTOR SHALL PROVIDE, FURNISH AND INSTALL, NEW FIXED 
TEMPERATURE HEAT DETECTORS IN THE WORK AREA DURING CONSTRUCTION AND THE 
HEAT DETECTORS ARE PROVIDED AS AN INTERIM EQUIVALENT SAFETY MEASURE TO BE 
PROVIDED DURING A FIRE ALARM OR FIRE SUPPRESSION SYSTEM IMPAIRMENT, 
RENOVATION TO THE EXISTING BUILDING'S SCOPE OF WORK AREA. COORDINATE WITH VA 
CONTRACTING OFFICER REPRESENTATIVE AND DESIGNATED FIRE SAFETY OFFICIAL. 
3. THE HEAT DETECTORS SPACING WITHIN THE CONSTRUCTION AREAS SHALL FOLLOW NFPA 
72 AND NFPA 241 REQUIREMENTS. THE HEAT DETECTORS SHALL BE 
CONFIGURED/INTERFACED WITH THE NEW LOCAL FIRE ALARM PANEL AND THE SITE'S 
EXISTING MAIN FIRE ALARM AND DETECTION SYSTEM FOR MONITORING DURING A SYSTEM 
IMPAIRMENT AND DURING THE RENOVATION OF EXISTING CONDITIONS FOR THIS SCOPE OF 
WORK. 
4. THE INTERIM FIRE DETECTION SYSTEM SHALL BE FULLY OPERATIONAL PRIOR TO ANY 
SIGNIFICANT COMBUSTIBLE MATERIALS ARE PRESENT WITHIN THE PERIMETER OF THE 
BUILDING. 
5. THE INTERIM FIRE DETECTION SYSTEM FOR  RENOVATED AREAS AND NEW CONSTRUCTION 
BUILDING SHALL INCLUDE THE HEAT DETECTORS INCLUDING ALL WIRING, PROGRAMMING, 
ETC., TO/FROM THE INDIVIDUAL DEVICES, TO THE LOCAL FIRE ALARM PANEL AND INTERFACE 
WITH THE MAIN FIRE ALARM CONTROL PANEL FOR 24/7 MONITORING IS A PROJECT 
REQUIREMENT. THE TEMPORARY FIRE ALARM DEVICES SHALL BE REMOVED OR LEFT IN 
PLACE DEPENDENT ON THE COR'S REQUIREMENT. 
6. ALL SHUTDOWNS SHALL BE COORDINATED AND APPROVED THROUGH THE COR'S 
REPRESENTATIVE AND SHALL REQUIRE A MINIMUM OF 15 DAYS ADVANCED NOTICE, THIS 
TIME LENGTH MAY BE LONGER OF SHORTER FOR SOME SHUTDOWNS AND SHALL BE AT THE 
COR'S DISCRETION. DRAINING AND REFILLING OF THE EXISTING SYSTEM IS A 
RESPONSIBILITY OF THE COR'S REPRESENTATIVE. 
7. ALL DISRUPTIONS IN THE FIRE SUPPRESSION SYSTEM SHALL BE COMPENSATED WITH AN 
APPROVED FIRE WATCH AND STANDBY PERSONAL. 
INTERIM FIRE ALARM, FIRE EXTINGUISHERS AND FIRE SUPPRESSION REQUIREMENTS 
E. FIRE EXTINGUISHERS REQUIREMENTS: 
a. THE RENOVATION OF THE EXISTING SCOPE OF WORK SPACE IN THE EXISTING VA MEDICAL 
CENTER SHALL REQUIRE THE PLACEMENT OF FIRE EXTINGUISHERS AS FOLLOWS: 
• FIRE EXTINGUISHERS SHALL BE LOCATED SO THAT THE TRAVEL DISTANCE TO A FIRE 
EXTINGUISHER DOES NOT EXCEED FIFTY FEET. 
• FIRE EXTINGUISHERS TO BE PROVIDED DURING CONSTRUCTION SHALL BE A 10 LB., FIRE 
EXTINGUISHER DRY CHEMICAL (4A:80B:C) FOR HEALTH CARE OCCUPANCIES TO INCLUDE 
THIS PROJECT'S SCOPE OF WORK SPACE. 
F. FLAMMABLE AND COMBUSTIBLE LIQUIDS: 
a. STORAGE OF FLAMMABLE AND COMBUSTIBLE LIQUIDS SHALL BE IN ACCORDANCE WITH 
NFPA 30 AND NFPA 241, SECTION 5.5 
G. FIRE SUPPRESSION REQUIREMENTS DURING CONSTRUCTION: 
a. FIRE SPRINKLER PROTECTION: 
• AUTOMATIC SPRINKLER PROTECTION SHALL BE PROVIDED AND INSTALLED WITH 
TEMPORARY SPRINKLER HEADS AS SOON AS PRACTICABLE. 
• THE INSTALLATION SHALL BE IN ACCORDANCE WITH NFPA 13 AND MEET THE 
REQUIREMENTS OF NFPA 241, SECTION 8.7.3. 
• OPERATION OF VALVES: OPERATION OF SPRINKLER CONTROL VALVES SHALL BE 
PERMITTED ONLY BY AUTHORIZED PERSONNEL AND SHALL BE ACCOMPANIED BY 
NOTIFICATION OF DULY DESIGNATED PARTIES. WHEN THE SPRINKLER SYSTEM IS BEING 
REGULARLY TURNED OFF TO FACILITATE CONNECTION OF NEWLY COMPLETED 
SEGMENTS, THE SPRINKLER CONTROL VALVE SHALL BE CHECKED AT THE END OF EACH 
WORK DAY TO ASCERTAIN THAT THE PROTECTION IS IN SERVICE.
